meanings.definition: abbreviation for Accident and Emergency: the part of a hospital where people go when they are ill or injured and need treatment quickly
an unpleasant or painful situation or person that you have to accept and deal with, although you find it very difficult
an occasion when you examine or explain the whole of a subject, method, or piece of work quickly without stopping or getting slower:
examples: In this book, John Pemble takes a brisk trot through the history and mysteries of Venice.

meanings.definition: a lot of something:
examples: I've got a whole heap of work to do.

bad-workman-blames-his-tools.name: a bad workman blames his tools

meanings.definition: said when someone has blamed a mistake or failure on the things that they use to work
a particularly good or successful period of time:
examples: 2004 was a banner year for astronomy.
Technology stocks had a banner month, rising 6.9 per cent.

meanings.definition: a very difficult first experience of something:
examples: I was given a million-dollar project to manage in my first month - it was a real baptism of fire.

meanings.definition: a great number of complaints, criticisms, or questions suddenly directed at someone:
examples: The TV station has received a barrage of complaints about the amount of violence in the series.
He faced a barrage of questions over his handling of the problem.
The measures received a barrage of criticism in the financial press.

meanings.definition: a number of things of a similar type:
examples: In the kitchen an impressive battery of stainless steel utensils hangs on the wall.

She faced a battery of questions from reporters gathered outside her home.
He went on TV to deliver a battery of statistics intended to justify his proposals.
The show uses a battery of theatrical effects.

meanings.definition: a pile of one type of food on which other food is arranged as a meal:
examples: roasted vegetables on a bed of rice
Serve the beef on a bed of polenta with mushrooms and peppers.
Pile the avocados on a bed of lettuce.
You could serve the fish on a bed of lightly cooked greens.

meanings.definition: something that you ask someone to do or hope that will happen, but that will be difficult to achieve:
examples: If the operations in Japan are successful, then the business should have a future, but it's a big ask.

meanings.definition: a weak and cowardly (= not brave) man:
examples: He's just a big girl's blouse.

meanings.definition: a very large number:
examples: There were billions of flies everywhere.
Billions of ads like these are posted on the Internet.
You know that road - we've driven down it a billion times!
There are billions of plastic bags in the cupboard under the sink.
You've got a billion pens - you don't need any more!
I've made billions of cakes like this over the years.

bird-in-the-hand-is-worth-two-in-the-bus.name: a bird in the hand (is worth two in the bush)

meanings.definition: said when you recognize that you should not risk losing something you already have by trying to get something you think might be better
the ability to look at something from a very high place so that you see a large area below you:
examples: From the top of this building, you can get a bird’s-eye view of the city.

meanings.definition: too extreme or not reasonable:
examples: I think it's a bit much for you to expect me to do all the cleaning.
She wore an expensive suit and diamonds, which was a bit much for such a casual restaurant.
Eealier on she liked all the attention but then it got to be a bit much.
I don't know about expecting people to work for ten hours at a stretch - I think it's asking a bit much.
It seems a bit much to ask her to take on caring duties as well as everything else that she does.

meanings.definition: a young man who has sex with a lot of different women
a sexually attractive woman:
examples: Have you seen his latest bit of skirt?

meanings.definition: a sexual partner, usually a man, from a low social class:
examples: Jenny's chatting up the barman again. She likes a bit of rough.

meanings.definition: a small piece or amount of something:
examples: Would you like a bit of chocolate?
I found a bit of cheese in the fridge.

She dabbed a bit of cream on her skin.
He used a bit of cloth to clean the screen.

meanings.definition: a slight but not serious amount or type of something:
examples: Maria's put on a bit of weight, hasn't she?
It's a bit of a nuisance.
Getting all the children ready on time can be a bit of a challenge.
The realization that I had left my phone at home sent me into a bit of a panic, but it was fine.
I suppose I felt a bit of envy, too.
It caused a bit of confusion, but it was soon sorted out.

meanings.definition: a sexual relationship with someone who is not married to you, or the person you have the relationship with:
examples: We've thought for a while that he was having a bit on the side.

meanings.definition: some food:
examples: You'll feel better once you've had a bite to eat.

meanings.definition: something that is very unpleasant but must be accepted:
examples: Losing to a younger player was a bitter pill to swallow.

meanings.definition: a thick covering of something:
examples: The ground was covered by a thick blanket of snow.

meanings.definition: something or someone that surprises you because you had almost forgotten about it
something that has a very powerful or noticeable effect:
examples: The garden is a blaze of colourin autumn.
She so badly wanted to end her career with a spectacular win – to go out in a blaze of glory.
His book was launched in a blaze of publicity.
Last week, the presenter stepped down from his 15-year role on the breakfast show in a blaze of controversy.

meanings.definition: something that seems bad or unlucky at first, but results in something good happening later:
examples: Losing that job was a blessing in disguise really.

meanings.definition: something that seems bad or unlucky at first but causes something good to happen later:
examples: Being laid off was a blessing in disguise – within a month I got a much better job.

meanings.definition: an idea or answer that suddenly becomes obvious:
examples: The answer came to her in a blinding flash.

meanings.definition: a great effort to improve something or do something that needs to be done:
examples: We had a blitz on the house at the weekend and cleaned it completely.

meanings.definition: a fault that spoils someone's reputation
something such as an ugly building that spoils a pleasant view
a person whose name is very well known to the public:
examples: The chef is a boldface name in Britain.
The scheme attracted thousands of investors, including some boldface names.
She's dated several boldface names.
A number of boldface names feature in his diaries.
Boldface names have always been used to sell products such as perfume.
What was noticeable at the conference was the distinct lack of boldface names.

meanings.definition: a person whose name is very well known to the public:
examples: She was a boldfaced name in newspaper gossip columns.
There was a distinct lack of boldfaced names in the show.
There was the usual stream of anecdotes from the actor, filled with boldfaced names.
The actress had long been a boldfaced name in Italian newspaper gossip columns.
Yet there is one boldfaced name omitted from the book.
Strangely, boldfaced names were few and far between at the ceremony.

meanings.definition: something important or unusual that happens suddenly or unexpectedly:
examples: The resignation of the chairman came like a bolt from the blue.

bolt-from-out-of-the-blue.name: a bolt from/out of the blue

meanings.definition: something completely unexpected that surprises you very much:
examples: The news of his marriage was a bolt from the blue.

meanings.definition: something that two or more people argue about strongly over a long period of time
something that two people or groups cannot agree about:
examples: Money is a common bone of contention in many marriages.

meanings.definition: the act of telling someone forcefully to start doing something more quickly or actively:
examples: She's so lazy - she needs a good boot up the backside.

meanings.definition: the smallest amount of wind:
examples: There wasn't a breath of air in the room.

A few wispy clouds hung in the sky, without a breath of air to move them.
The sea looked like glass that day. There wasn't a breath of air.

meanings.definition: a short period of time spent outside:
examples: I'm just going out for a breath of (fresh) air - I won't be long.

meanings.definition: someone or something that is new and different and makes everything seem more exciting:
examples: Angela's so cheerful and lively - she's like a breath of fresh air when she visits.

meanings.definition: someone or something that makes a situation feel new, different, and exciting:
examples: The last band was a breath of fresh air in an otherwise boring night of music.

meanings.definition: a mood in which you are quiet, thinking a lot, and paying attention to your own thoughts rather than what is going on around you:
examples: I sat in a brown study for a long time after I had finished reading the letter.

meanings.definition: a situation in which you experience something, or almost experience something, especially something unpleasant:
examples: Jim had a brush with death (= was nearly killed) on the motorway.
Was that your first brush with the law (= experience of being in trouble with the police)?

After his latest brush with infamy, the footballer is keen to stay out of the tabloids and is keeping a low profile.

meanings.definition: something, usually something not very serious, that delays a process or prevents it from developing:
examples: As with any new programme, there are going to be bumps in the road.
This year's disappointing scores are more like a bump in the road leading towards continued improvement.
Almost 90 percent of companies surveyed feel the current economic slowdown is a bump in the road and that growth will resume in six to nine months.

meanings.definition: If you give someone a bunch of fives, you hit them hard with your hand closed.
a funny, entertaining person or situation:
examples: He's not exactly a bundle of laughs, is he?

meanings.definition: someone who is extremely nervous and worried:
examples: Sorry for shouting - I'm a bundle of nerves these days.

meanings.definition: someone who is extremely nervous:
examples: Since the robbery, I’ve been a bundle of nerves.

meanings.definition: sung by a group of people without any musical instruments
an example that shows that what you are saying is true or helps to explain why you are saying it:
examples: Lack of communication causes serious problems and their marriage is a case in point.
There's a real lack of science teachers. My son's school provides a case in point where an English teacher is now delivering science lessons.
Not all schools are able to fundraise, and this school provides a case in point. Many of our parents are poor or recent immigrants and don't have either the spare cash or spare time to give.
The quality of health care is declining rapidly. Case in point: your mother's recent experience in hospital.
Some can be transmitted without obvious symptoms, this disease being a case in point.

meanings.definition: used when a situation is of a particular type:
examples: She doesn't want to work full-time - it's a case of having to.
The police suspect that it was a case of mistaken identity.
Ultimately, it's a case of weighing the risk against the potential benefit.
Fitness is for everyone. It's just a case of finding an exercise regime that fits in with your lifestyle.

This isn't just a case of technology being difficult for older users - the design of this phone is genuinely terrible for everyone.

change-is-as-good-as-a-rest.name: a change is as good as a rest

meanings.definition: You can get as much good from changing the work you do as from having a rest.
a set of clothes as well as the ones that you are wearing:
examples: You'll need a change of clothes if you're staying overnight.

You will need to bring at least two changes of clothes.
Patients on this ward are given a change of clothes daily.
I always keep a change of clothes in my locker at work.

meanings.definition: an unfair, negative remark made by someone to achieve an advantage over someone else :
examples: Making fun of his name was a cheap shot.
Everyone in the region is upset at what they consider a cheap shot.

meanings.definition: a sudden, violent, physical move against a player who was not prepared for it:
examples: They will be taking a hard look at the grabbing of helmets and the cheap shots in the scrum.
There's no reason for any player to take a cheap shot like that.

meanings.definition: an unfair, negative remark made by someone to achieve an advantage over someone else:
examples: Making fun of his name was a cheap shot.

meanings.definition: (in some sports) a sudden, violent, physical move against a player who was not prepared for it
a situation in which it is impossible to say which of two things existed first and which caused the other one
someone who has been very influenced by a particular period or situation:
examples: Me, I'm a child of the 60s.
People should never forget that I'm a child of poverty.
He was a child of the Great Depression, who was forced to work from the age of ten.

I'm a child of the civil rights movement, and I expect justice for all.

chip-off-the-old-block.name: a chip off the old block

meanings.definition: someone who is very similar in character to their father or mother
an angry attitude from someone who feels unfairly treated:
examples: She’s not going to make any friends if she walks around with a chip on her shoulder like that.

meanings.definition: an opinion given by a large group of people at the same time, or a large group of people giving their opinion:
examples: The publication of the book was greeted with a chorus of acclaim.

meanings.definition: an official statement that something has been found to be safe, legal, or in good financial condition:
examples: Two of the bridges got tentative clean bills of health from inspectors on the scene Friday.

meanings.definition: a state in which you are starting an activity or process again, not considering what has happened in the past at all:
examples: The previous negotiations did not go anywhere, and we intend to start them again next week with a clean slate.

meanings.definition: a situation in which one player, team, etc. wins everything that is available:
examples: Romania made a clean sweep of the medals.

meanings.definition: a quick hit on the side of someone's head:
examples: You do that once more and you'll get a clip round the ear, my lad.

meanings.definition: a situation in which something bad, unpleasant, or dangerous almost happens, but you manage to avoid it:
examples: It was a close call for residents when a tornado swept through just west of the town.

meanings.definition: something bad that almost happened:
examples: The car just missed the child but it was a very close thing.

meanings.definition: a situation or future event that makes you worry or feel unhappy:
examples: When you're waiting for an operation, you feel like there's a cloud hanging over you.

meanings.definition: something that threatens to cause problems or unhappiness in the future:
examples: The only cloud on the horizon is the physics exam in June.

meanings.definition: a member of a large organization whose job, although necessary, makes them feel as if they are not important:
examples: I decided to set up my own business because I was tired of just being a cog in a machine.

meanings.definition: a position or view from which a lot of land can be seen:
examples: The house occupies a commanding position at the top of the valley.

meanings.definition: a combination of words that is nonsense because some of the words suggest the opposite of some of the others:
examples: Many people think that an honest politician is a contradiction in terms.

meanings.definition: a victory in which the person or team that wins is much better than the person or team they are competing against:
examples: They won a convincing victory.

meanings.definition: two or a few more:
examples: They scored three goals and could have got a couple more.

meanings.definition: two or a few things that are similar or the same, or two or a few people who are in some way connected:
examples: We'll see you in a couple of weeks.

I just wanted to add a couple of things.

meanings.definition: to be so good or successful that the people or things that made you successful should be mentioned:
examples: Thomas is a credit to our school system.

meanings.definition: a sudden loss of confidence:

meanings.definition: a rude phrase for something that is not true:

meanings.definition: a way of saying that you need help:

meanings.definition: a great misfortune:

meanings.definition: a young woman who is in trouble and needs a man's help
a situation or future event that causes worry, problems or unhappiness:
examples: Weaker demand is not the only dark cloud looming over the tech industry.

delicate-situation-matter-point-etc.name: a delicate situation, matter, point, etc.

examples: I need to speak to you about a delicate matter.

meanings.definition: a lot of something:

meanings.definition: something that you remember slightly, but not very well:
examples: I had a dim recollection of having met her before.

meanings.definition: common and not special:

meanings.definition: a dangerous situation in which something very bad is very likely to happen:

meanings.definition: someone who keeps something that they do not want in order to prevent someone else from getting it
something or someone that looks extremely untidy, or something that is very badly done
a very unhappy and unpleasant life
a plan that has been formally arranged or agreed and that is now certain to happen:
examples: Although it has yet to happen, reform of the sector is regarded as a done deal.

meanings.definition: something good that someone wanted very much to happen but seemed very unlikely, that does in fact happen:
examples: Winning all that money was a dream come true.

meanings.definition: a very small amount compared to the amount needed:
examples: All the money we raised was just a drop in the bucket.

meanings.definition: something small and unimportant, esp. when compared with something else:
examples: We were paid about $50,000, but that was a drop in the bucket compared to what some other companies got.

meanings.definition: a very small amount compared to the amount needed:
examples: My letter of protest was just a drop in the ocean.

meanings.definition: too much alcohol to drink

meanings.definition: said about someone who is in a very difficult situation, and who will take any available opportunity to improve it
a type of person or thing that is becoming rare:
examples: Authentic blues singers are a dying breed these days.

meanings.definition: something unpleasant that cannot be avoided:
examples: Going bald is just a fact of life.

fair-crack-of-the-whip.name: a fair crack of the whip

meanings.definition: an equal chance to do something:
examples: It's only right that all the candidates should be given a fair crack of the whip.

meanings.definition: an opportunity to explain something or give your opinions, without other people trying to influence the situation:
examples: He didn't think that he got a fair hearing in court.

I'm sure the legislation got a fair hearing - I'm just surprised it didn't pass.

meanings.definition: an equal chance to do something:
examples: It's only right that all the candidates should be given a fair shake.

meanings.definition: something you do not want to experience because it is so unpleasant:
examples: When you're 16, an evening at home with your parents seems like a fate worse than death.

meanings.definition: something you do not want to experience because it is so unpleasant or embarrassing:
examples: Being seen with my parents at the beach would have been a fate worse than death.

meanings.definition: an achievement to be proud of:
examples: It's a real feather in our cap to be playing in the state championship.

meanings.definition: an achievement to be proud of:
examples: The award was another feather in his cap.

meanings.definition: a short distance:
examples: The museum is just a few steps from the hotel.
A couple of steps in any direction is green, open land.
There is a good primary school just a step down the road from where they live.

meanings.definition: a short speech:
examples: He introduced the visitors with a few well-chosen words.

meanings.definition: a result is equally likely to happen or not happen:
examples: There’s only a fifty-fifty chance that she’ll survive the operation.

meanings.definition: a situation in which two groups or people intend to fight until one side has been defeated
something imagined or created by your mind:
examples: The dinosaurs he said he saw were figments of his imagination.

fine-figure-of-a-man-woman.name: a fine figure of a man/woman

meanings.definition: a person who is tall, with a large, physically attractive body
If you say that there is a fine line between one thing and another, you mean that they are very similar. You often say this when one thing is acceptable and the other is not:
examples: As a parent, I knew that there was a fine line between panic and caution.

meanings.definition: a very small difference between two things that may seem different:
examples: There’s sometimes a very thin line between love and hate.
As a comedian, I’m always walking that fine line between humor and sarcasm (= finding a balance between them).

meanings.definition: strong control:
examples: Reforming these young offenders will require a firm hand.

meanings.definition: a person who feels awkward or unhappy because they are in a situation that is not familiar or because they are different from the people around them:
examples: I didn't have any friends that were like me. I just always felt like a fish out of water.
He loves being married and if he wasn't he'd be like a fish out of water.

meanings.definition: someone who is uncomfortable in a specific situation:
examples: I felt like a fish out of water at my new school.

meanings.definition: If someone goes on a fishing expedition, they attempt to find evidence that someone has done something illegal or interesting, but without saying that this is the purpose of their search:
examples: This was so obviously a fishing expedition from the start to see if there was anything the police could charge me with.

meanings.definition: a very angry argument in which people shout at each other:
examples: We had a flaming row over it last night.

meanings.definition: something that happened only once or for a short time and was not repeated:
examples: Sadly, their success was just a flash in the pan.

meanings.definition: something that is interesting for only a short time:
examples: The band was just a flash in the pan with one hit in 2003.

flush-of-anger-excitement-pleasure.name: a flush of anger, excitement, pleasure, etc.

meanings.definition: a sudden strong feeling of anger, excitement, pleasure, etc.:
examples: Lena felt a flush of shame at the memory.

meanings.definition: something that you would like to be true but that is probably not:
examples: I waited at home all evening in the fond hope that he might call.

force-to-be-reckoned-with.name: a force to be reckoned with

meanings.definition: If an organization or a person is described as a force to be reckoned with, it means that they are powerful and have a lot of influence:
examples: The United Nations is now a force to be reckoned with.

meanings.definition: for an even stronger reason than one that has already been accepted:
examples: The proposition is incomprehensible to us, and hence a fortiori we cannot be justified in believing it.

meanings.definition: used to describe an argument that gives a stronger reason than one that has already been accepted:
examples: his a fortiori argument

meanings.definition: an advantage that someone gets without paying for it or earning it:
examples: Minimum price agreements can discourage discounters from taking a free ride on other retailers' promotional efforts.

meanings.definition: to get an advantage without paying for it or earning it:
examples: They continue to try to free-ride on the efforts of others to slow global climate change.

friend-in-need-is-a-friend-indeed.name: a friend in need is a friend indeed

meanings.definition: This means that a friend who helps you when you really need help is a true friend.
difficulty speaking because your throat feels dry:
examples: I had a frog in my throat, and I had to clear my throat several times before I could answer.

meanings.definition: an offer by a college or university to pay all costs for the studies of a person with great ability:
examples: My friend's nephew just got a full ride to Princeton.
Robinson accepted a football full ride at his dad's alma mater.

full-good-thick-etc-head-of-hair.name: a full, good, thick, etc. head of hair

meanings.definition: a lot of hair:
examples: Even as a tiny baby, she had a thick head of hair.

meanings.definition: something that results from something else, or is the way it is because of something else:
examples: His success is a function of his having worked so hard.
The low temperatures here are a function of the terrain as much as of the climate.
Differences in health outcomes are often said to be a function of socioeconomic disparity.

meanings.definition: someone who can behave, work, and live in a way that seems normal although they are addicted to (= unable to stop using too much) alcohol, drugs, etc.:
examples: While functional alcoholics drink excessively, most do not display the obvious physical or psychological damage associated with alcoholism.

meanings.definition: someone who can behave, work, and live in a way that seems normal although they are addicted to (= unable to stop using too much) alcohol, drugs, etc.:
examples: She was a highly successful athlete and a functioning alcoholic.
What do you do if you discover that your loved one is a functioning addict?
Would you say he was a high functioning alcoholic?

meanings.definition: a lot of something:
examples: She has a fund of knowledge on the subject.

meanings.definition: a meeting of rich and famous people:

meanings.definition: If a sports team has a game in hand over other teams in a competition, it still has an extra game to play in which it can gain points:
examples: Fulham are third from bottom with two games in hand over the teams below them.

meanings.definition: an especially good or lucky thing or person that comes to you
a type or amount of drink contained in a glass:
examples: Would you like a glass of water?
Two glasses of lemonade, please.

Could you pour me a glass of wine, please?

meanings.definition: an expression in your eyes that shows that you are amused or that you have a secret:
examples: "I can't tell you that yet, but I will soon," Grandpa said with a gleam in his eye.

meanings.definition: an expression in your eyes that shows that you are amused or that you have a secret:
examples: "I can't tell you that yet, but I will soon," Grandpa said with a gleam in his eye.

meanings.definition: an extremely small distance or amount:
examples: His finger came within a gnat's whisker of being chopped off.

meanings.definition: much:
examples: The new law met with a good deal of opposition at the local level.

meanings.definition: someone who gives you a lot of attention when you are talking about your problems or things that worry you, and tries to understand and support you
a lot of:
examples: There were a good many people at the concert.

meanings.definition: someone who helps people in trouble

good-time-was-had-by-all.name: a good time was had by all

meanings.definition: said to mean that everyone enjoyed themselves
a statement of approval and support for someone or something:

meanings.definition: an activity or piece of work that appears to be done with great, little, etc. effort:

meanings.definition: a painting or other image of a person that looks very like them:

meanings.definition: to be worth/not be worth the price:
examples: This jacket is a really good buy, at £200.

In your opinion, which of these shares is the better buy?

meanings.definition: someone who is good/bad at meeting new people and talking to them:
examples: You get to know lots of people at college if you're a good mixer.

She's a very nice person but, alas, a bad mixer.

meanings.definition: someone who is not/often ill when travelling by boat:

meanings.definition: an action that helps/harms someone:
examples: That's my good turn for the day!

meanings.definition: a large amount:

meanings.definition: someone who sleeps in the stated way:

meanings.definition: someone who is skilled/not skilled at aiming and firing a gun:

meanings.definition: a lot of similar things or remarks, thrown or shouted at someone at the same time:

meanings.definition: a very small distance or amount:
examples: His finger was within a hair's breadth of touching the alarm.

meanings.definition: a problem that is very difficult to solve or a person who is very difficult to understand
a difficult situation to deal with:
examples: Teachers have a tough row to hoe in today's schools.

meanings.definition: the ability to be in a high place without feeling fear:

meanings.definition: the force produced by a large amount of steam in a closed space

meanings.definition: a kind and generous character:

meanings.definition: a planned meeting between two people who are very interested in having a romantic or sexual relationship:

meanings.definition: a feeling of unhappiness:

meanings.definition: used for emphasis to mean "very":

meanings.definition: a large amount of money:

meanings.definition: someone who saves you from a difficult or dangerous situation

meanings.definition: in the style of:

meanings.definition: in the most modern style or fashion
served with ice cream:

meanings.definition: something you do without being certain what will happen as a result:

meanings.definition: an act of believing something that is not easily believed:

meanings.definition: an act of believing something that is not easily believed:

meanings.definition: a situation that is fair because everyone has the same chance of succeeding:

meanings.definition: a quick and careless act of cleaning or washing

meanings.definition: slightly:

a long-haul airline/carrier/trucker

meanings.definition: said to mean that you will do whatever you have to do, even if it is difficult or dangerous

examples: Terry's what you'd call a man's man - you wouldn't find him at the ballet too many nights a week.

meanings.definition: someone who keeps their promises:

meanings.definition: someone who has a lot of experience of life and people, and can deal with most situations

meanings.definition: a situation that involves varying levels of something rather than two completely different things:

meanings.definition: something that depends on personal preference:

meanings.definition: only; just:

meanings.definition: used when you think that something will happen at some point in the near future:

meanings.definition: something you do in order to achieve something else:

meanings.definition: a situation when two or more people have the same opinions about something
a symbol that represents a particular thing:
examples: The author uses disease as a metaphor for the corruption in society.

meanings.definition: very quickly:
examples: Mike was very excited, talking a mile a minute.

meanings.definition: a large number:

meanings.definition: someone who has a lot of knowledge

meanings.definition: a short time during which someone makes a bad decision or does something bad that they would not normally do:

meanings.definition: a large amount of something:

meanings.definition: an activity that will not make you happy or successful:

meanings.definition: something I do not understand:

meanings.definition: a success that was almost a failure:
examples: We caught the ferry but it was a narrow squeak.

meanings.definition: a very unpleasant person
something that is impossible or extremely difficult to find, especially because the area you have to search is too large:
examples: Finding the piece of paper I need in this huge pile of documents is like looking for/trying to find a needle in a haystack

meanings.definition: said when someone new takes control of an organization and makes many changes
an occasion when you become more energetic and active than before:
examples: His grandchildren have given him a new lease of life.

meanings.definition: an occasion when you become more energetic and active than before:

meanings.definition:

meanings.definition: If a competition is nip and tuck, first one side seems to be winning and then the other, so that the result is not certain:

meanings.definition: in a situation in which one side seems to be winning and then the other, so that the result is uncertain:

nod-is-as-good-as-a-wink.name: a nod is as good as a wink

meanings.definition: used to say that only a slight sign is needed for you to understand clearly what is meant by something or what is happening in a situation
If something is a nod to a particular thing, it refers to it:
examples: The name San Francisco 49ers is a nod to the prospectors who flocked to California during the 1849 gold rush.

meanings.definition: someone that a person has sex with, not because they want a serious relationship, but because they want to have sex with as many people as possible:

meanings.definition: several of a particular type of thing:

meanings.definition: someone who collects things that they do not need:

meanings.definition: an important part of the history of a place, time, or group of people:

meanings.definition: used to refer to a woman as a sexually attractive object
something that is very easy to do:

meanings.definition: infml a part of the profits or advantages that come from an activity:

meanings.definition: a share of something:

meanings.definition: a share of something:

meanings.definition: a very unkind or unpleasant person:

meanings.definition: something that you buy or accept without first seeing it or finding out if it is good

a good or lucky position:

relating to an argument that suggests the probable effects of a known cause, or using general principles to suggest likely effects:

I can't believe that, with all the lawsuits against him, he's thinking of running for office. What a snake.
Be careful around Ryan - he's a snake and will absolutely take advantage of you.

meanings.definition: a situation in which something increases in size or importance at a faster and faster rate:
examples: The more successful you become, the more publicity you get and that publicity generates sales. It's a kind of snowball effect.

meanings.definition: a man who was born in a particular place:
examples: that notable son of Württemberg, Martin Brecht
The much admired poet and writer, Philip Larkin, himself a son of Coventry, was born in 1922.
We gather here today to pay tribute to a notable son of this city.
I am, of course, quoting Dylan Thomas, that much celebrated son of Swansea.
From this very house, that celebrated son of Boston, Paul Revere, set off for his famous ride.

meanings.definition: If you walk with or have a spring in your step, you walk energetically in a way that shows you are feeling happy and confident:
examples: There's been a definite spring in his step ever since he met Joanna.

meanings.definition: going back to a worse or less developed state:
examples: The changes that have been introduced are being seen as a step backward.

meanings.definition: going back to a worse or less developed state:
examples: The changes that have been introduced are being seen as a step backwards.

meanings.definition: to reduce the amount, supply, or rate of something, usually gradually:
examples: The doctor has said that I can start stepping down my medication in a few days' time.
This device is used for stepping down the voltage.

meanings.definition: reducing gradually:
examples: With this step-down mortgage, interest rates start at 6.99% in the first year and drop on a sliding scale to 5.99% after four years.
It’s a step down method to ease smokers and society into a smoke-free environment.

meanings.definition: involving gradually reducing the amount of special care or support that someone gets:
examples: They believe the law lacks a step-down program that would allow offenders to transition back into the community.
In the step down house, a small number of men, still supported but with increasing levels of independence, readjust to life in the community.

meanings.definition: cared for in, or relating to, a part of a hospital that is for people who no longer need intensive care (= continuous treatment for patients who are seriously ill, very badly injured, or who have just had an operation) but still need special care that cannot be provided on normal wards:
examples: Our step-down patients are complex post-cardiac surgery patients who need closer monitoring and an increased level of care.
B10 is a nursing unit with 5 step-down beds.
The patient was transferred to a step-down unit to continue the recovery process.

meanings.definition: used for describing a piece of equipment that decreases voltage (= the force of an electric current), or the decreased voltage itself:
examples: A transformer with fewer turns on the secondary coil than on the primary coil is described as a step-down transformer.
The device integrates one high-voltage step-down converter and one low-voltage step-down converter.
A plug-mounted transformer which provides a step-down voltage may be used.

meanings.definition: used for describing something such as a room that is at a lower level, so that you have to step down to walk into it:
examples: The house has a step-down living room.
The luxury villa has a four-poster bed, step-down shower, and an open terrace.

meanings.definition: a reduction in something:
examples: There has been a definite step-down in trading across the high street in the past two weeks.
A step down in playing standards was to be expected.

meanings.definition: part of a hospital that is for people who no longer need intensive care (= continuous treatment for patients who are seriously ill, very badly injured, or who have just had an operation) but still need special care that cannot be provided on normal wards:
examples: I got a job at the university hospital on the trauma step-down.
Three days after the operation, they transferred her from intensive care to step-down.

meanings.definition: to give up a job or position:
examples: She stepped down as captain of the team.

meanings.definition: to offer to provide or do something, or to help with something:
examples: No one has yet stepped forward to claim responsibility for the attack.
At the last minute another company stepped forward with a bid.

meanings.definition: to offer to provide or do something, or to help with something:
examples: No one has yet stepped forward to claim responsibility for the mistake.
At the last minute another company stepped forward with a bid.

step-in-the-right-direction.name: a step in the right direction

meanings.definition: a change or development that increases the chances of success:
examples: Not everybody sees the changes as a step in the right direction.
This plan isn't perfect, but it's a step in the right direction.

meanings.definition: an action or event that helps someone or something to progress towards a particular aim:
examples: He has made an important step on the road to recovery and rehabilitation after his accident.
Getting a job was my first step on the road to freedom.
After 15 minutes they scored again, taking a giant step down the road to victory.
The company has taken another step down the road of modernization.
This is not a solution, but it is a step along the road towards reconciliation.

meanings.definition: to take action when there is a need or opportunity for it:
examples: Investors have to step up and assume more responsibility for their assets.
This is a real crisis. Someone needs to step up.

meanings.definition: to increase the size, amount, or speed of a process :
examples: The police are stepping up their efforts to fight crime.
Security has been stepped up at the airport.
Note that if the voltage is stepped up, the current must be stepped down, and vice versa.

meanings.definition: used for describing a piece of equipment that increases voltage (= the force of an electric current):
examples: It is described as a step-up transformer because the output voltage is greater than the input voltage.
If you're taking a hairdryer, travel iron or anything else that requires a lot of power, you will need a step-up adaptor.

meanings.definition: involving stepping on something that is at a higher level than the floor:
examples: The fitness assessment included a step-up test to measure aerobic ability.
Special child seats with handles and step-up blocks are available.

meanings.definition: an increase in something:
examples: There was a step-up in airport security after the attack.
The step-up to 15 miles will suit some runners.

meanings.definition: the act of stepping on something that is at a higher level than the floor:
examples: A step-up is a simple exercise that works muscles in the legs and buttocks.
All those step ups had left her with big calf muscles.

meanings.definition: to take action when there is a need or opportunity for it:
examples: Investors have to step up and assume more responsibility for their assets.

meanings.definition: to make something more effective, or to increase the size or speed of something:
examples: Efforts were stepped up in Congress to pass the bill.

meanings.definition: to increase the size, amount, or speed of a process in order to achieve something:
examples: We need to step up production in order to meet our deadline.

meanings.definition: a large increase:
examples: We have seen a step-up in profits

meanings.definition: a rise to a higher level, rank, etc.:
examples: This was the biggest step-up of his career.

stick-to-beat-with.name: a stick to beat someone with

meanings.definition: something that you can use to criticize, influence, or cause difficulty for someone or something you dislike or disapprove of:
examples: The country's lack of openess was used as a stick to beat it with.

meanings.definition: a strong wind:
examples: We live near the ocean, where stiff breezes cleanse the air.
We were tired from riding our bikes into a stiff breeze.
The buildings are so flimsy, they look like they might fall over in a stiff breeze.
A stiff wind made it difficult to throw the ball across the field.
Spores from the plants can carry many miles in a stiff wind.

stiff-drink-brandy-gin-etc.name: a stiff drink, brandy, gin, etc.

meanings.definition: an alcoholic drink that is very strong:
examples: A stiff whisky - that's what I need.
He poured himself a stiff drink and sat in his armchair.
I need a stiff drink after that meeting!
It took a stiff gin to calm her down.
Why don't we go to the bar and have a couple of stiff brandies?

meanings.definition: said to mean that it is better to act or deal with problems immediately, because if you wait and deal with them later, things will get worse and the problems will take longer to deal with
a short distance:
examples: The animal was sitting just a stone's throw away from us.
The lodge is within a stone’s throw of the ski slopes.

meanings.definition: a very short distance:
examples: The apartment is just a stone's throw from the sea.
"Is your house far from here?" "No, it's only a stone's throw away."

meanings.definition: something that provides a lot of information, ideas, memories, etc.:
examples: The Internet is a storehouse of electronic information.
He was great company and a storehouse of entertaining anecdotes.
The local people are a storehouse of traditional knowledge.
This book is a storehouse of information for anyone interested in photography.
When workers rotate between tasks, they build up a storehouse of knowledge.

stroke-of-luck-genius-etc.name: a stroke of luck, genius, etc.

meanings.definition: something that happens or succeeds suddenly because of luck, intelligence, etc.:
examples: By a stroke of luck, someone else was walking along the trail and heard my shouts for help.
Painting the wall blue was a stroke of genius.
By a stroke of fortune, she escaped serious injury.
It was a stroke of back luck that I was chosen to go first.
His arrival in the town was a stroke of luck for us.

meanings.definition: a method or a type of behaviour that involves using force and threats to make people do what you want:
examples: Police resorted to strong-arm tactics to break up the protest.
They were criticized for their strong-arm tactics for recovering loan money.
Businesses have complained that lawyers are using strong-arm tactics to extract compensation payments for their clients.
Local police used strong-arm methods to deal with the crowd.
He was notorious for using strong-arm methods to silence his critics.

meanings.definition: something certain to win or succeed:
examples: Your promotion is a sure thing – you’re the best person for the job.

meanings.definition: the fact of liking or enjoying something:
examples: She came home from Europe with a taste for art and the finer things in life.
Scientists think our ancestors developed a taste for meat around 2.5 million years ago.
I developed a taste for travel while working in Hong Kong.
If you don't give your child junk food, they won't get a taste for it.
Many of these workers were developing a taste for middle-class pleasures.

meanings.definition: something that no longer happens:
examples: Giving up your seat to an older person seems to be a thing of the past.

meanings.definition: some matters, facts, or information:
examples: I'm having trouble paying attention - I have a thing or two on my mind.
Why don't you ask Andrew about it? He knows a thing or two about (= has some knowledge of) computers.
She thinks she knows everything about raising children, but I could tell her a thing or two (= some information she does not know).

meanings.definition: a large number:
examples: I have a thousand things to do before we go away.
We've got thousands of these things knocking around the office.
I've heard him use that phrase a thousand times.
A thousand things went through my mind.
You don't need any more books - you have thousands of them!
You've done this sort of thing a thousand times.

meanings.definition: a period when you experience a lot of problems
infmlso good that whatever happens next is unlikely to seem as good:
examples: The last Bond movie was my favorite - it'll be a tough act to follow.

meanings.definition: a difficult situation to deal with:
examples: The candidate has a tough row to hoe – he has limited funds, and his message is not a popular one.

meanings.definition: someone who is very unpleasant and difficult to deal with:
examples: As a teenager, Jack was a real hard nut, always getting into fights.

meanings.definition: a particular type of person or thing, especially one that is difficult to deal with:
examples: David can be a very tough customer when he perceives others as obstacles to achieving his goals.
The Sars virus is turning out to be a tricky customer.
The team desperately need a win, and that will make them very difficult customers.
Johnson is an interesting customer; he has been described as the best bowler of his generation.

meanings.definition: someone or something that remains strong and gives a lot of support in a difficult situation:
examples: Andrea was a tower of strength to me when I was ill.
Although she is softly spoken and gentle, she is a pillar of strength for her family.
In later life, his early religious and philosophical ideas proved a tower of strength.
At that time, Europe was seen as a much-needed pillar of strength in a global economy.

meanings.definition: a place that is full of something good:
examples: a treasure trove of information
Though small, this museum is a veritable treasure trove of history.
In fact, the whole book is a treasure trove of obscure information.
The exhibition turned out to be a treasure trove of memories for my elderly grandma.
The research resulted in a treasure trove of invaluable data.

meanings.definition: an action that makes a bad situation worse, especially one that forces someone to do something:
examples: Each letter from my bank is another turn of the screw.

meanings.definition: an appearance of agreement:
examples: The party's main failing has been their inability to present a united front to the people.

It's really important for parents to show a united front when dealing with difficult children.

meanings.definition: something that is very easy to do, and usually pleasant:
examples: He's used to hard physical work - this is a walk in the park to him.

meanings.definition: someone who seems to be a human form of disaster, encyclopedia, etc.:
examples: You broke another pair of glasses? You're just a walking disaster!
Your dad's a walking legend!

meanings.definition: used to warn someone of danger or an accident that seems likely to happen:
examples: "Watch out!" he shouted, but it was too late - she had knocked the whole tray of drinks onto the floor.

meanings.definition: last week on:
examples: The problem with the TV started a week ago Monday.

meanings.definition: in one week following:
examples: The first performance of the play is a week from tomorrow.

meanings.definition: a very boring and disappointing experience or person:
examples: He sounds about as much fun as a wet weekend in Carmarthenshire.

meanings.definition: used to refer to a very great amount of something or a very good thing:
examples: That's a whale of a story.
Another thousand dollars would make a whale of a difference.

meanings.definition: a large amount of something:
examples: A whale of a lot of other people were there, too.
Perry's done a whale of a job for us.

meanings.definition: a slight sign of something:
examples: They regularly hold elections without a whiff of corruption or violence.
I thought I detected a whiff of desperation in his voice.
There's just a whiff of snobbery in some of the criticism.
There's more than a whiff of nostalgia about shows such as these.
Isn't there a whiff of hypocrisy around this?
For me, the whole concept still has a whiff of elitism.

meanings.definition: a large number or amount of something:
examples: The reorganization will give us a whole bunch of problems.

meanings.definition: very much:
examples: Things were about to get a whole lot worse.

meanings.definition: all of something, or all of the people or things in a group:
examples: I offered him some chocolate, and he ate the whole lot.

meanings.definition: a completely different situation, often one that is difficult or that you know little about:
examples: We'd done a lot of climbing in Scotland but the Himalayas were a whole new ballgame.

meanings.definition: an experience that is extreme in some way, for example very fast, difficult, excellent, etc., often in a way that is exciting:
examples: This week was such a wild ride!

Congratulations on the new job, and get ready for a wild ride.
Every day since has been a wild ride, from starting to promote the book to the day that it hit the top of the bestseller list.

meanings.definition: a person with a pleasant and friendly appearance that hides the fact that they are evil
someone or something that seems to be good but is actually not good at all:
examples: My grandfather was a wolf in sheep’s clothing – he looked like a sweet old man, but he was really mean.

meanings.definition: a piece of advice or information that is given to someone secretly:
examples: If you are still on friendly terms with your ex, have a quiet word in his ear about the problem.

meanings.definition: If there is a world of difference between two people or things, they are very different:

meanings.definition: (an example of) illegal noisy or violent behaviour in a public place:
examples: Ten percent of this group were in persistent trouble for minor breaches of the peace.

meanings.definition: said when you want to know what another person is thinking, usually because they have been quiet for a while
I would like to know what you are thinking:
examples: You haven't said very much – a penny for your thoughts.

meanings.definition: used to describe something approximately:
examples: It's a sort of pale orange colour.

meanings.definition: in some way or to some degree:
examples: I was sort of hoping to leave early today.
It's sort of silly, but I'd like a copy of the photograph.

meanings.definition: in some way or to some degree:
examples: I feel sort of sorry for him, even though I know he's not a nice person.

meanings.definition: used when you are about to give a piece of advice or information to someone in an informal way:
examples: A word to the wise: always check opening hours in advance.

A word to the wise - this looks like a sound investment.

a note in Western music:
examples: This concerto is in the key of A major.

examples: Sophie got an A for English.

a knife and fork

a bit of wool

meanings.definition: used in front of someone's family name when they are a member of that family:

meanings.definition: used before the name of a day or month to refer to one example of it:

meanings.definition: one:

to leave a place, thing, or person, usually for ever:

meanings.definition: to stop doing an activity before you have finished it:

The manager made a pitching change in the sixth inning with one out and two runners aboard.

meanings.definition: on or onto a ship, aircraft, bus, or train:
examples: We finally went aboard the plane three hours later.

meanings.definition: the place where someone lives:
examples: Welcome to my humble abode!
The defendant is of no fixed abode (= has no permanent home).
Please list your permanent address or, if you are a citizen of another county, the address of your habitual abode in this country.
Despite being called The Cottage, their estate was the largest abode in the county.
I bought you some nice candlesticks for your new abode.

meanings.definition: the place where someone lives:
examples: He was a wanderer with no permanent abode.

meanings.definition: a home or permanent place to live:
examples: He voted to allow 50,000 Hong Kong families the right of abode in Britain.

meanings.definition: to end an activity or custom officially:
examples: I think bullfighting should be abolished.
National Service was abolished in the UK in 1962.

meanings.definition: to put an end to something, such as an organization, rule, or custom:
examples: Massachusetts voters abolished rent control.

meanings.definition: to end an activity, custom, etc. completely or by law or official action:
examples: Educationalists have called on the government to abolish tax on computers.
The government has pledged to abolish child poverty by 2020.

examples: The river was once a trade route for aboriginals and fur traders who built communities along its bank.

examples: The Arunta are an aboriginal tribe from central Australia.

meanings.definition: having lived or existed in a place since the earliest known time:
examples: The exhibit was of aboriginal plants of this area.

to cause something to stop or fail before it begins or before it is complete:

meanings.definition: to stop the development of a baby that has not been born, usually by having a medical operation:

meanings.definition: to have a miscarriage (= an early, unintentional end to a pregnancy):

meanings.definition: to stop a computer process before it is complete:

examples: The coast here abounds with rare plants.

meanings.definition: positioned around a place, often without a clear purpose or order:
examples: Their belongings were flung about the room.

meanings.definition: in a particular place:
examples: Do you have such a thing as a pen about you/your person? (= Do you have a pen?)
She was puttering about the kitchen.

meanings.definition: a little more or less than the stated number or amount:
examples: about six feet tall
about two months ago
"What time are you leaving work today?" "About five."

meanings.definition: almost:
examples: We're about ready to leave.
Well, I think that's about it for now (= we have almost finished what we are doing for the present).

meanings.definition: in many different directions:
examples: They heard someone moving about outside.
I've been running about all morning trying to find you.

meanings.definition: positioned around a place, often without a clear purpose or order:
examples: She always leaves her clothes lying about on the floor.

meanings.definition: in or near a place:
examples: Is John about (= somewhere near)?
There's a lot of flu about (= many people have the flu) at the moment.

meanings.definition: on the subject of; connected with:
examples: "What’s that book about?" "It’s about the Civil War."
I don’t know what all the fuss is about.
There’s something about her attitude that worries me.

meanings.definition: a little more or less than a specific number; approximately:
examples: He’s about six feet tall.
It happened about two months ago.
I’ve had just about enough of your complaining (= I do not want to hear any more).

meanings.definition: almost ready to do something, or intending to do something soon:
examples: He looked as if he was about to burst into tears.
I’m not about to apologize to him.

meanings.definition: positioned or moving in or near a place:
examples: Reporters stood about, waiting for more news.

meanings.definition: If it is about time/high time that someone did something, it should have been done sooner or a long time ago:
examples: It's about time that the school improved its food service.
It is high time for the critics to open their minds to a new approach.
It's about time we had a female leader.
It's about time we fixed this law.
It's high time companies like those started paying more tax.
It's high time we reduced the number of vehicles on our roads.

meanings.definition: said when someone does something or something happens that you think should have been done or have happened much sooner:
examples: "So Ben's finally found a job." "Yeah, it's about time."
"By the way, Abbie's paid me the money that she owes me." "About time too!"
"Dylan apologized to me today for his comments on Saturday." "Good - about time!"
"Lucy finally called this afternoon." "Yeah, well, not before time."
It's about time that Lucas finally agreed to pay for the damage! I never thought he'd do it.

meanings.definition: a change of direction:
examples: I had to do an about-face and turn right instead of left.
The plane made an about-face and headed back to the airport.

meanings.definition: a complete change of opinion or behaviour:
examples: The senator's about-face on the issue caught his supporters by surprise.
After being confronted by her constituents, the representative did an about-face and came out in support of the bill.
After resisting the change, the company made an about face and embraced the new technology.

meanings.definition: a complete change of direction, opinion, or way of acting
About-face is also an order given to soldiers to tell them to turn around and face the other way.
a change of direction:
examples: The dog did an about-turn and ran when it saw the bigger dog.
I hadn't gone far when I remembered I hadn't locked the door, so I made a quick about-turn and went back.

meanings.definition: a complete change of opinion or behaviour:
examples: Predictably, the lawmaker did an about-turn on the issue when he realized how unpopular his position was with taxpayers.
The government official made an about-turn and agreed to the meeting.
The reversal is one of the biggest about-turns in parliamentary history.

meanings.definition: in or to a higher position than something else:
examples: There's a mirror above the sink.
He waved the letter excitedly above his head.
She's rented a room above a shop.
Her name comes above mine on the list.
The helicopter was hovering above the building.
It's on the shelf just above your head.
A crack had started to appear just above the light on the ceiling.

meanings.definition: more than an amount or level:
examples: Rates of pay are above average (= greater than average).
It says on the box it's for children aged three and above.
Temperatures rarely rise above zero in winter.
She values her job above her family.
They value their freedom above all else.

meanings.definition: in a more important or advanced position than someone else:
examples: Sally's a grade above me.

meanings.definition: too good or important for something:
examples: No one is above suspicion in this matter.

meanings.definition: When used in a piece of writing, "above" means higher on the page, or on a previous page:
examples: Please send the articles to the address given above.
The letter was sent to the above address.

meanings.definition: higher than, more than, or at a level greater than:
examples: The helicopter was hovering above the building.
Temperatures here rarely rise above freezing in winter.
Our wages are above average.
I could hardly hear him above the blare of the music.

meanings.definition: In writing, above can mean as stated higher up on this page or on a previous page:
examples: Refer to the diagram shown above.

meanings.definition: To be above doing something is to consider yourself too important or too moral to do it:
examples: He’s not above lying to protect himself.

meanings.definition: those mentioned earlier:
examples: All of the above are to be included.

meanings.definition: most importantly:
examples: Above all, I'd like to thank my family.
Above all, I'd say I value kindness.
This book is above all a story of a mother's love.
Any furniture you buy must be cheap, attractive and, above all, practical.
His goal, above all, was to prevent another war.

meanings.definition: more than a particular amount or level:
examples: We have faced costs far above and beyond what was anticipated.
Gifts above and beyond the $11,000 annual limit may be subject to tax.

meanings.definition: If a plan or business agreement is above board, it is honest and not trying to deceive anyone:
examples: The deal was completely open and above board.

meanings.definition: done in an honest way, according to the rules or law:
examples: The bidding process was completely fair and above board.

meanings.definition: relating to bonds, shares, etc. that are selling at more than their face value (= the value shown on them):
examples: Stock bought above par will result in a capital loss.

meanings.definition: better than usual, or above the expected standard:
examples: The food in the hotel is well above par.

meanings.definition: in the top part of a newspaper page:
examples: The stories that the editor feels will sell the newspaper are put above the fold.

meanings.definition: in the top part of a website page which you can see on the screen when you first open the page:
examples: The attention-grabbing part of the home page needs to be placed above the fold.

meanings.definition: higher or better than the usual amount or level:
examples: We believe in above-average pay to attract above-average people.
We expect to see continuing above-average growth.
Women's participation in the workforce in Ireland is now above average by international standards.

meanings.definition: used to refer to things or people in a document or book that have been mentioned earlier:
examples: All of the above-mentioned movies won Oscars.
I strongly disagree with the last paragraph of the abovementioned article.
Major changes were made in the laws of England during the period above-mentioned.

meanings.definition: relating to advertising on television, in newspapers, on the internet, etc. rather than to other ways of telling people about a company or product:

above-the-line advertising

meanings.definition: a rude and unfriendly way of talking or behaving:

meanings.definition: to experience emotions that you have tried to forget, usually when working with a psychotherapist (= someone who treats mental illness by discussing someone's problems with them):
examples: The aim of many psychotherapy techniques is to get the client to abreact.

meanings.definition: the experiencing of emotions that you have tried to forget, usually when working with a psychotherapist (= someone who treats mental illness by discussing someone's problems with them):
examples: The resurfacing of these repressed memories that you are experiencing is what we call abreaction.

meanings.definition: next to another person and facing in the same direction:

meanings.definition: If you keep abreast of a subject, you stay informed about new developments in it:
examples: Staying abreast of new software releases takes lots of time.

meanings.definition: to make a book, play, or piece of writing shorter by removing details and information that is not important:

examples: He said that Congress would make no law abridging the freedom of speech.

meanings.definition: sudden and unexpected, and often unpleasant:

meanings.definition: an end that is sudden and unexpected, and often unpleasant:

meanings.definition: the fact of not being where you are usually expected to be:
examples: A new manager was appointed during her absence.

meanings.definition: the fact of not existing:

meanings.definition: the state of not being somewhere, or a period in which you are not somewhere:
examples: She has had repeated absences from school this year.

meanings.definition: An absence can also be a lack of existence:
examples: He drew attention to the absence of any solid evidence against the defendant.

meanings.definition: a time when someone is not at work or at the place they are expected to be:
examples: Her absence from the meeting was noted.

meanings.definition: the fact that something is not where it is needed or expected:
examples: The business was suffering from an absence of an overall plan for moving forward.
In the absence of any alternative, we'll continue in the same way as before.

meanings.definition: This means that when people we love are not with us, we love them even more.
not in the place where you are expected to be, especially at school or work:

meanings.definition: not existing:

meanings.definition: used to describe a person or the expression on a person's face when they are thinking about other things and are not paying attention to what is happening near them
without:

meanings.definition: not at work or at the place where you are expected to be:

meanings.definition: not existing in a particular place:

examples: Soldiers officially become deserters after being absent without leave for more than 30 days.

meanings.definition: away without permission or agreement from a place where you are supposed to stay:

In order to take part in the championships, he went absent without leave from his job as an accountant.

meanings.definition: Someone who is absent-minded often forgets things or does not pay attention to what is happening near them because they are thinking about other things:
examples: His wife described him as "a classic absent-minded professor."
She is kindly but absent-minded, often forgetting appointments and birthdays.

meanings.definition: likely to forget things, esp. because you do not give your attention to what is happening
without paying attention to what you are doing or what is happening near you because you are thinking about other things:
examples: She absent-mindedly left her umbrella on the bus.
He went to call his wife, only to absent-mindedly dial his boss.
I sat there staring absent-mindedly out of the window.

meanings.definition: a lack of attention to what you are doing or what is happening around you because you are thinking about other things:
examples: In a moment of absent-mindedness, she threw her keys in the bin.
Missing the meeting was not absent-mindedness, it was deliberate.

meanings.definition: someone who is not at school or work when they should be:
examples: There are several absentees from school this week, because a lot of people have flu.

meanings.definition: someone who is absent
someone who is not at work or at the place where they are supposed to be:

meanings.definition: a system of voting in which people send their votes by post when they cannot be present at an election
a piece of paper on which people mark their votes and then send them by post when they cannot be present at an election
an official paper that someone who cannot be at the voting place on the day of an election can use for voting and can send in by mail
a person who rents out a house, apartment, or farm to someone, but never or almost never visits it
a person who rents a property to someone, but who does not live in or visit the property:
examples: Absentee landlords who fail to maintain their properties are bringing down property prices in the neighbourhood.

meanings.definition: a vote sent by post or by using the internet, rather than by a person physically attending an election:
examples: With overseas absentee votes counted, he was in the lead.

meanings.definition: a system of voting in which people send their votes by post or by using the internet, rather than physically attending an election:
examples: He asked lawmakers to facilitate an absentee vote.

meanings.definition: someone who sends their vote by post or by using the internet, rather than being physically present to vote at an election:
examples: His campaign courted absentee voters - the growing segment who vote by mail instead of at the polls.

meanings.definition: the system or action of sending votes or a vote by post or by using the internet, rather than being physically present to vote at an election:
examples: The county plans to do away with poll voting in favour of absentee voting, saying two-thirds of voters already vote by mail anyway.

meanings.definition: a situation in which people are not at school or work when they should be:

meanings.definition: the fact of staying away from work, especially without a good reason:
examples: The high levels of absenteeism at the company were caused by poor management.

meanings.definition: as if you are not paying attention to what is happening near you, and are thinking about other things:
examples: He stared absently at his food.

meanings.definition: a strong alcoholic drink that is green and has a bitter taste
very great or to the largest degree possible:
examples: a man of absolute integrity/discretion

meanings.definition: used when expressing a strong opinion:
examples: He's an absolute idiot!
That's absolute rubbish!

meanings.definition: true, right, or the same in all situations and not depending on anything else:
examples: an absolute law/principle/doctrine
Do you think there's such a thing as absolute truth/beauty?
Her contribution was better than most, but in absolute terms (= without comparing it with anything else) it was not very good.

meanings.definition: An absolute ruler has unlimited power:
examples: an absolute monarch

meanings.definition: without limit, very great, or to the largest degree possible:
examples: She demanded absolute silence.

meanings.definition: certain; not to be doubted:
examples: Health insurance is an absolute necessity.

meanings.definition: very great or to the largest degree possible:
examples: The board said they had absolute confidence in the CEO, despite the company's difficulties.

meanings.definition: used when expressing a strong opinion:
examples: It's an absolute disgrace!

meanings.definition: an advantage a country has because it can produce a particular type of product more cheaply than another country:
examples: China has an absolute advantage over Japan in toy production.

meanings.definition: an auction (= type of sale) where something is sold to the person who offers the most money, and does not have a reserve price (= minimum sale price):
examples: Although the seller was disappointed by the bid, he had no choice but to sell since the vehicle was sold in an absolute auction.

meanings.definition: political or legal control that is not limited by anyone or anything:
examples: The Constitution grants the president absolute authority on this point.

meanings.definition: the ability to control something without being limited by anyone or anything:
examples: The manager requires absolute authority regarding all football-related decisions.
The engineer appointed to lead a new project is given a huge budget and near absolute authority over key decisions.

meanings.definition: the distance between two numbers on a number line, represented as the larger number minus the smaller number:
examples: At age 65-69, the absolute difference between the proportions of men and women reporting no disability is only six percent.
The absolute difference in time between the two approaches is quite minimal, less than one millisecond.

meanings.definition: the difference between a number, size, value, etc. that you measure or predict and the correct number, size, value, etc. :
examples: Table 5 shows the absolute errors between the actual values and predicted values.
For systems with high reliability, the absolute error is about 0.0001.

meanings.definition: the actual amount of water that is present in the air:
examples: Despite the abundance of frozen water in the Antarctic, the absolute humidity is lower than in the Sahara Desert.
Absolute humidity is expressed in grams per cubic centimetre.

meanings.definition: a calculation of the relationship between the speed of light moving through a medium (= substance) and the speed of light in a vacuum (= an area with no matter in it):
examples: So how do you calculate the absolute index of refraction?

meanings.definition: a situation in which one person or political party wins more than half of the total votes in an election
a situation in which one person or party wins more than half of the total votes in an election:
examples: The President has an absolute majority in the National Assembly.

meanings.definition: the highest value across a whole domain (= range) of a function:

meanings.definition: the lowest value across a whole domain (= range) of a function:

meanings.definition: a situation where only one company, country, etc. produces and sells a particular product:

meanings.definition: the fact of owning something completely, without any limits:

meanings.definition: the fact of owning land or property completely, without any possibility that someone else can prove they have a right to it:

meanings.definition: a legal arrangement in which a person gives an individual or organization control of their money or property after their death, and names the person or people who will receive it at a particular time. These details cannot later be changed:
examples: Your children will automatically become entitled to money held in an absolute trust at age 18.

meanings.definition: the distance from zero of a number on a number line
the distance from zero of a number on a number line

completely:
examples: I believed/trusted him absolutely.

meanings.definition: used for adding force to a strong adjective that is not usually used with "very" or to a verb expressing strong emotion:
examples: It's absolutely impossible to work with all this noise.

meanings.definition: used as a strong way of saying "yes":

meanings.definition: completely; beyond any doubt:

meanings.definition: Absolutely is also used in conversation to show emphasis in agreeing to something:
examples: "Can you lend me $10 till tomorrow?" "Absolutely, it’s no problem."

meanings.definition: If you say absolutely not, you are showing emphasis in not agreeing to something:
examples: "You mean you won’t sign this?" "No, absolutely not."

meanings.definition: used as a strong way of saying "no":

a political system in which a single leader controls all branches of government and has authority over everyone and everything in the country

examples: The report absolved her from/of all blame for the accident.

meanings.definition: to take something in, especially gradually:
examples: Our countryside is increasingly being absorbed into large cities.

meanings.definition: to take up someone's attention completely:
examples: The project has absorbed her for several years.

meanings.definition: if a business absorbs the cost of something, it pays that cost easily:
examples: The school has absorbed most of the expenses so far, but it may have to offer fewer places next year to reduce costs.

meanings.definition: if one company absorbs another company, it takes control of it and they become one company:

meanings.definition: if an organization absorbs the cost of something, it pays that cost:

meanings.definition: if one company absorbs another company in a takeover, they become one company:

meanings.definition: Something that is absorbing is very interesting and keeps your attention:

meanings.definition: the ability of an organization to discover and use new ideas or technology to help its activities or business:

meanings.definition: the ability of someone to understand facts or ideas completely and remember them:

meanings.definition: the ability of a material or surface to absorb (= to take in and hold) a liquid or other substance, or to take in and hold heat or energy:

meanings.definition: used to describe a policy or a type of education that teaches people that they should not have sex outside of marriage, and does not teach about any other methods of preventing pregnancy or disease:

meanings.definition: existing as an idea, feeling, or quality, not as a material object:
examples: Truth and beauty are abstract concepts.

meanings.definition: An abstract argument or discussion is general and not based on particular examples:
examples: This debate is becoming too abstract - let's have some hard facts!

meanings.definition: used to refer to a type of painting, drawing, or sculpture that uses shapes, lines, and colour in a way that does not try to represent the appearance of people or things:
examples: abstract art
an abstract painter

meanings.definition: a short form of a speech, article, book, etc., giving only the most important facts or ideas:
examples: There is a section at the end of the magazine that includes abstracts of recent articles/books.

meanings.definition: a painting that uses shapes, lines, and colour in a way that does not try to represent the appearance of people or things
to consider something in a general way or make a general judgment after looking at particular details:
examples: Most interviewees focus on their own experience and do not generalize or abstract the situation.

meanings.definition: to remove or separate someone or something from a place or context (= the situation, facts, words, etc. that exist around something):
examples: It was impossible to abstract children from their social environment with all its dangers.
