meanings.definition: to give a summary or abstract (= a short description giving the most important ideas) of something:
examples: If you find an article you think should be abstracted in our journal, submit it for consideration.

meanings.definition: existing as an idea, feeling, or quality, not as a material object:
examples: "Humanity" is an abstract idea.

meanings.definition: If a statement, argument, or discussion is abstract, it is general and not based on particular examples.

examples: abstract art

meanings.definition: a few sentences that give the main ideas in an article or a scientific paper
existing as an idea, feeling, or quality, not as a material object:
examples: "Satisfaction" is difficult to measure as it is an abstract concept.

meanings.definition: a shortened form of a speech, article, book, etc., giving the most important facts or ideas:

meanings.definition: a style of art, beginning in the 1940s, that tries to express feelings and emotions with abstract images that use lines and colour in a way that does not try to represent people or things:
examples: She played a substantial role in the history of modernism and abstract expressionism.

meanings.definition: a noun that refers to a thing that does not exist as a material object:
examples: "Happiness", "honesty", and "liberty" are abstract nouns.

meanings.definition: a set of documents showing all the previous owners of a piece of land or property:

meanings.definition: not giving attention to what is happening around you because you are thinking about something else:

meanings.definition: without paying attention to what is happening around you because you are thinking about something else:

meanings.definition: the quality of existing as or representing an idea, a feeling, etc. and not a material object, or something that has this quality:
examples: They discuss the issue of realism versus abstraction in sculpture.

meanings.definition: the quality of being very general and not based on real examples, or something that has this quality:

meanings.definition: the action of removing or separating something from a place or context (= the situation, facts, words, etc. that exist around something), or something that is removed like this:

meanings.definition: an idea that develops by looking at or thinking about a number of different things

meanings.definition: in a general way, not based on particular examples:

meanings.definition: not known or understood by many people:

meanings.definition: stupid and unreasonable, or silly in a humorous way:

meanings.definition: ridiculous or completely unreasonable:

meanings.definition: the quality of being stupid and unreasonable, or silly in a humorous way:

meanings.definition: something that is stupid or unreasonable:

meanings.definition: an agreement or contract between an insurance company and a customer to provide insurance:
examples: This life insurance plan offers guaranteed acceptance for the over 50s.

meanings.definition: approval of a new machine, computer system, etc. after testing it to check that it works correctly:
examples: A number of acceptance tests were performed.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         accepting house
an amount of money that is paid to someone for joining a company or for agreeing to do something:
examples: New associates receive an acceptance bonus of $10,000 before they start working.

meanings.definition: a way of testing the quality of a group of things by examining a sample (= a small number of them) in order to decide whether to accept the whole group:
examples: Acceptance sampling is used to monitor the quality of incoming materials.

meanings.definition: a test of new equipment by a customer in order to check that it works correctly:
examples: Before any software is installed, a full test and user acceptance trial must be completed.

meanings.definition: the accepted meaning of a word:
examples: I may not be an athlete in the common acceptation of the word, but I enjoy regular workouts at the gym.
He claimed that the word "emigrant" in its present acceptation was not then in use.
Two interpretations can be equally legitimate when, by common acceptation, a term has acquired a secondary meaning.

meanings.definition: generally agreed to be satisfactory or right:
examples: "Speed bump" now seems to be the generally accepted term for those ridges in the road that slow traffic down.

meanings.definition: opinions or theories that have existed for a long time and that most people agree with, even if they are not true or correct:
examples: The article questions the accepted wisdom that high cholesterol is bad.
For years, the accepted wisdom among psychologists has been that those patterns don't change.

meanings.definition: willing to allow or approve of something or someone, or to consider something as normal:
examples: They found the locals to be generally accepting of their religion.
I feel truly safe here. The people are very accepting and non-judgmental.

meanings.definition: one of several large banks in London in the past that received bills of exchange (= written orders to pay someone a particular sum of money)
an atom or molecule that receives electrons to form a chemical substance
an atom or molecule that receives electrons to form a chemical substance
a bank or person that agrees to pay a draft or bill of exchange (= written orders to pay someone a particular amount of money):
examples: The party to whom the bill of exchange is addressed is called the acceptor.

meanings.definition: the method or possibility of getting near to a place or person:
examples: The only access to the village is by boat.
The main access to (= entrance to) the building is at the side.
The children's father was refused access to them at any time (= refused official permission to see them).

meanings.definition: the right or opportunity to use or look at something:
examples: The system has been designed to give the user quick and easy access to the required information.
We were able to gain access to the safe.
Hackers had complete access to the company files.

meanings.definition: to be able to get to or get inside a place:
examples: It is too difficult for anyone using a wheelchair to access the building.
Students need a card to access restricted areas such as residences and labs.
The basement room is accessed from outside.

meanings.definition: to be able to use or obtain something such as a service:
examples: Older people may have difficulty accessing medical services.
It needs to be easier for small businesses to access government resources and advice.

meanings.definition: to open a computer file, a website, etc. in order to look at or change information in it:
examples: Most people use their phones to access the internet.
You have to enter a password to access the database.
A hacker remotely accessed the company's servers (= was able to look at information stored on the company's servers using a computer located in a different place).

meanings.definition: the method or way of approaching a place or person, or the right to use or look at something:
examples: Without an official pass, the guards will deny you access to (= will not let you enter) the courthouse.

meanings.definition: Access to something can also mean the opportunity or ability to use it:
examples: Many of the families do not have access to health care.

meanings.definition: to get information, esp. when using a computer:
examples: People now can access information from the Internet as never before.

meanings.definition: the right or opportunity to use or receive something:
examples: Community radio stations have access to public funding.
Everyone is entitled to fair access to employment.

meanings.definition: the right or ability to look at documents and information:
examples: She was granted access to the official archives.
You can gain access to your records via this website.
They planned to restrict access to their website content with the use of a subscription system.
Merchants have online access to their product data.
Auditors have unrestricted access to all records.

meanings.definition: the ability to use a system such as the internet, or the way in which you can do this:
examples: Do you have access to the internet?
Business travellers expect free internet access.
broadband/wireless access

meanings.definition: the method or possibility of getting to or entering a place:
examples: The site has easy access to the motorway.
The premises are equipped for disabled access.

meanings.definition: the right or ability to buy and sell goods in a particular country or market:
examples: Our website gives us access to global markets.

meanings.definition: the right to use a bank account, or to remove money from a bank account or an investment:
examples: Some accounts allow instant access to your savings.

meanings.definition: the legal right to see your child or children, or other family member, especially after a divorce:
examples: Many fathers go to court to seek access to their children.

meanings.definition: to open a computer file or to use a computer system such as the internet:
examples: Many users now access the internet via their mobile phones.
I can access my email remotely.

meanings.definition: to look at a bank account, and be able to move money into or out of it:
examples: You can access your account online or by phone.

meanings.definition: to be able to get or use something, especially a service:
examples: We advise staff on how to access appropriate training.

meanings.definition: a series of numbers and/or letters that allow the user to get into a place or to use a computer system or website:
examples: When you subscribe, you will be emailed an access code which will allow you to gain entry to the subscription site.
Even the low-security areas like this one required an access code.

meanings.definition: a series of numbers used before the main phone number when you call someone outside your own area or country:
examples: The international access code for Egypt is +20.
First dial the access code from your country to the UK.

meanings.definition: ways of controlling who can enter a building or area, usually involving electronic technology:
examples: The buildings are secured with an access control system.

meanings.definition: ways of controlling who can see or enter information on a computer system:
examples: We ensure that proper security and access controls are in place to protect your data.

meanings.definition: in the UK, a set of classes that people take so they can get a qualification that can be used to get into university or college:
examples: She didn't have any formal qualifications but took an access course to get into university.

meanings.definition: a piece of computer equipment that allows computers to be connected together without wires to share information:
examples: Wireless networks need an access point, or base station - a node that funnels data to and from the Web.

meanings.definition: a company that allows you to use the internet and use email, and gives you space on the internet to put your documents:
examples: the UK's largest internet access provider

meanings.definition: easy to understand:

meanings.definition: if a person is accessible, they are willing to see people and are friendly and easy to talk to:
examples: You will find all our staff friendly and accessible.

meanings.definition: in a way that can be easily obtained or reached:

meanings.definition: in a way that can be reached or used by all people, including those who cannot walk well, or who cannot see, hear, etc.:
examples: The toilets are all located accessibly on the ground floor.

meanings.definition: the time when someone starts a position of authority, especially a king or queen:
examples: 1926 was the year of Emperor Hirohito's accession to the throne.

meanings.definition: the time when a country officially joins a group of countries or signs an agreement:

examples: All genes identified and characterized in this study have been submitted to GenBank and assigned accession numbers.

meanings.definition: a muscle, nerve, or gland that increases or strengthens the effect of another muscle, nerve, or gland

meanings.definition: something added to a machine or to clothing that has a useful or decorative purpose:
examples: Sunglasses are much more than a fashion accessory.

meanings.definition: someone who helps another person to commit a crime but does not take part in it:
examples: He was charged with being an accessory to murder.

meanings.definition: something extra that improves or completes the thing it is added to:
examples: We sell plants, seeds, fertilizer, and gardening accessories, such as tools and gloves.

meanings.definition: a person who helps another person to commit a crime but does not take part in it:
examples: He was charged as an accessory to murder.

meanings.definition: someone who helps someone after that person has committed a crime, for example by hiding them from the police:
examples: She was charged with being an accessory after the fact.
He pleaded guilty to being an accessory after the fact.
He learned that he would be charged as an accessory after the fact for the murder count.
Witnesses who refuse to cooperate may become an accessory after the fact.
The jury found him not guilty of being an accessory after the fact.

meanings.definition: someone who helps in the preparation of a crime:
examples: The person who gave him the gun was an accessory before the fact.
He was charged as an accessory before the fact to murder.
His inflammatory words were enough to make him an accessory before the fact.
The court reversed her conviction of being an accessory before the fact to armed robbery.
The trial court will hear the accessory before the fact charges today.

meanings.definition: one of a pair of nerves that help the neck and shoulders to move:
examples: The accessory nerve provides motor function to two muscles essential to neck and shoulder movement.
Some sports injuries can cause accessory nerve damage.

meanings.definition: an extra electrical connection between one part of the heart and another that affects the heart's electrical system:
examples: accessory pathway tachycardia
The patient has been asymptomatic after ablation of the accessory pathway.

meanings.definition: used for showing that you agree with something or understand something:
examples: Accha, that's good. Go ahead!

meanings.definition: used for showing surprise or happiness:
examples: "I managed to buy it for half the price." "Accha!"

meanings.definition: a very short note that is played as a decoration before or starting together with the main note:
examples: On instruments that permit it, such as the piano, the acciaccatura is often sounded simultaneously with the principal note, and then immediately released.
Here, she finds a lighter, sharper style, with little ornamental acciaccaturas crisply played.

meanings.definition: something bad that happens that is not expected or intended and that often damages something or injures someone:
examples: Josh had an accident and spilled water all over his work.
The lorry had been involved in an accident.
The sign was damaged in an accident.
She was injured in a car/road accident (= when one car hit another).

meanings.definition: something that happens by chance, without anyone intending or planning it:
examples: Social status is often merely an accident of birth (= caused by whether people are born rich, poor, etc.).
I like to think it is not an accident that hidden in the word "created" are the letters R-E-A-D.
He became president by an accident of history.

meanings.definition: an event not intended by anyone but which has the result of injuring someone or damaging something:
examples: He was killed in an automobile accident at the age of 21.

meanings.definition: something that happens unexpectedly and unintentionally:
examples: It’s no accident that (= There are reasons that explain why) she was chosen to be a member of the most powerful committee in Congress.

meanings.definition: the part of a hospital where people go when they are ill or injured and need treatment quickly:
examples: We found more than one in ten, 11 percent, had been to accident and emergency in relation to drugs or drink.
Many clients choose to use the accident and emergency department of their local hospital instead of going to see their own doctor.

meanings.definition: a regular payment made by an insurance company or government to someone who cannot work because of an accident or illness:
examples: Donna now lives on accident and health benefits.

meanings.definition: insurance against injury or death caused by an accident:
examples: Personal accident insurance allows "no-fault" claims where there is a pay-out regardless of who's responsible.

meanings.definition: If someone's position or situation is an accident of birth, it is the result of where they were born or who their parents were. :
examples: I live here by choice rather than accident of birth.
He owes his love of Africa to an accident of birth.

meanings.definition: An accident-prone person often has accidents, usually because they are very awkward.
having or likely to have accidents frequently:
examples: Sleep-deprived kids are more accident-prone.

meanings.definition: happening or existing by chance:
examples: Reports suggest that eleven soldiers were killed by accidental fire from their own side.
The site was located after the accidental discovery of bones in a field.
He plays a naive salesman who becomes an accidental hero by saving a child's life.

meanings.definition: a sign showing that there is a temporary change from the key signature (= the set of musical notes that should normally be played for a particular piece of music)
a bird that is found in a place where birds of its type are not usually found :
examples: You may spot accidentals driven in by the stormy weather.

meanings.definition: a verdict (= an opinion stated at the end of a trial) that is given when a death was the result of an accident and not of murder or suicide

meanings.definition: If you do something accidentally on purpose, you do it intentionally but pretend it happened by chance:

meanings.definition: the process of changing to suit different conditions of life, weather, etc., or the act of making someone or something do this:
examples: Overseas drivers driving on the opposite side of the road for the first time may need a few days of acclimatisation.
Inadequate acclimatization may lead to altitude sickness above 8,000 ft.

meanings.definition: to change to suit different conditions of life, weather, etc., or to make someone or something do this:

meanings.definition: a special arrangement that is made for a person or group that has different needs to others:

examples: When two people from different social backgrounds meet, there is often a tendency for their ways of speaking to alter so that they become more alike, a process known as accommodation.

meanings.definition: a process in which a speech sound is changed according to the sound that comes directly before or after it:

meanings.definition: a relationship between two people who have met but do not know each other well:

meanings.definition: knowing or being familiar with a person:

meanings.definition: knowing or being familiar with someone or something:

meanings.definition: If you are acquainted with someone you know them, but not well:
examples: I am not personally acquainted with the gentleman in question.

meanings.definition: to acquire (= buy) a company in order to use its employees' skills or knowledge, rather than for its products or services:
examples: We recently acqui-hired a small Mexican start-up in order to expand our business in that area.

meanings.definition: the act of acquiring (= buying) a company in order to use its employees' skills or knowledge, rather than for its products or services:
examples: a report on how the company completed a successful acquihire

meanings.definition: to accept or agree to something, often unwillingly:
examples: Reluctantly, he acquiesced to/in the plans.

meanings.definition: to accept or agree to something, often without really wanting to:
examples: The bank acquiesced to an extension of the loan.

meanings.definition: able to be learned:

meanings.definition: An acquirable business, property, etc. is available be bought:
examples: At the time we were the only company in our sector that was publicly traded, and so we were acquirable.

meanings.definition: to get or obtain something:

meanings.definition: to buy a business or property, or buy shares in a business:
examples: He acquired the firm in 2008.
In 1949 the property was acquired by United Steel Companies.

meanings.definition: to buy or obtain the right to sell or publish something, for example the right to publish a particular work or the works of a particular writer:

Warner Bros. acquired the rights to the movie in North America.

meanings.definition: to gradually learn or gain something such as a language or skill:
examples: We want to understand more about how children acquire language.

He has acquired a reputation for being difficult to work with.

meanings.definition: to develop a medical condition or catch a disease that you were not born with:
examples: They develop gene therapy products for the treatment of acquired and inherited diseases.

meanings.definition: to obtain or begin to have something:
examples: His family acquired the property in 1985.

meanings.definition: to buy or take control of a company or part of a company, often by buying shares in it:

meanings.definition: to get the legal right to use or do something:

meanings.definition: to get something that is important to your business:

meanings.definition: to get something that is important to you in your job:
examples: Aptitude tests attempt to judge a person's ability to acquire new skills.

meanings.definition: to cause people to think a certain way about you because of your past activities or your character :

meanings.definition: to gradually develop a liking for something:

meanings.definition: something that someone buys, often to add to a collection of things:

meanings.definition: something such as a building, another company, or a piece of land that is bought by a company, or the act of buying it:

meanings.definition: used to describe a company that buys other companies:

meanings.definition: used to describe a person or company that buys other companies:

meanings.definition: eagerness to own and collect things:

meanings.definition: a person or company that buys other companies:

meanings.definition: to decide officially in a law court that someone is not guilty of a particular crime:

meanings.definition: the size of an area of land in acres (= a unit for measuring area, equal to 4,047 square metres or 4,840 square yards), or an area of land that can be measured in acres:

meanings.definition: an area of land measured in acres:

examples: Don't be so silly - you're acting like a child!

meanings.definition: to do something for a particular purpose or in a particular way:

meanings.definition: to perform in a movie, play, or television show:

meanings.definition: something that someone does:

meanings.definition: a law or formal decision made by a parliament or other group of elected law-makers:
examples: The 2010 act, with its requirement for a review of financial controls, has helped drive up the cost of corporate audits by as much as 50%.

meanings.definition: to do something with the intention of achieving a particular result:

meanings.definition: to do a particular job, especially one that you do not normally do:
examples: He was asked to act as an adviser on the project.

meanings.definition: to have a particular effect:
examples: Some people say that capital punishment acts as a deterrent.

meanings.definition: to do a particular job, especially one that you do not normally do:
examples: She has been asked to act as a negotiator on behalf of the factory.

meanings.definition: to have a particular effect:
examples: The launch of the new investment trust will act as a support for this market.

meanings.definition: If a lawyer or other professional acts for you, they represent you in order to deal with something. :
examples: Who is acting for the defendant?

meanings.definition: to represent a person, company, etc. in a court of law:
examples: There are few exceptions to the rule that a solicitor may not act for both seller and buyer.

meanings.definition: to represent a person, company, etc. or deal with their business for them:
examples: The Council of Mortgage Lenders claims to act for 98% of lenders.

meanings.definition: an action by someone who owes money that may give people they owe money to a reason to ask a court to say that they are bankrupt (= legally unable to pay what they owe and forced to give up control of their finances):
examples: This Agreement may be terminated if the other party commits any act of bankruptcy or has a receiving order made against it.

meanings.definition: something, especially something unnecessary and dangerous, that shows courage and that you do to make people respect or admire you:
examples: In an act of bravado, he challenged his opponent to a fight.
The whole escapade was an act of bravado that went horribly wrong.

meanings.definition: a new law that is made by the US Senate and House of Representatives, usually after it has been signed by the President:
examples: The overall settlement under discussion would require an Act of Congress, the report said.

meanings.definition: an action which shows that someone refuses to obey someone or something:
examples: She wore the badge as an act of defiance.

meanings.definition: an event such as a very bad storm that cannot be prevented or controlled and usually cannot be insured against:
examples: The insurance company dismissed the accident as an act of God and refused to pay out.

meanings.definition: a new law that is made by the UK House of Commons and House of Lords, which has to be signed by the Queen or King:
examples: The General Medical Council, set up by an Act of Parliament in 1858, has legal powers to act against doctors.

meanings.definition: to do something as a reaction to a particular thing such as an instruction, a feeling, or some information :
examples: There is no point soliciting feedback if you never act on it.

meanings.definition: to do something because you have been advised or told to do it:
examples: There have been concerns as to why the Board didn't act on a recommended pay raise.

meanings.definition: to behave badly because you are unhappy or upset, often in ways that you are not aware of:
examples: These kids act out because their lives are a mess.

meanings.definition: to perform the actions and say the words of a situation or story:
examples: The children acted out their favourite poem.

meanings.definition: to express your thoughts, emotions, or ideas in your actions:
examples: Children's negative feelings often get acted out in bad behaviour.

meanings.definition: to behave badly because you are unhappy or upset, often in ways that you are not aware of:
examples: These kids act out because their lives are a mess.

meanings.definition: to behave in a particular, usually bad, way:
examples: Why are you always acting the fool?

He seems to enjoy acting the buffoon.
They've behaved badly for years and now they're acting the victim.

meanings.definition: If a person, especially a child, acts up, they behave badly:
examples: Sophie got bored and started acting up.

meanings.definition: If a machine or part of the body acts up, it does not perform as well as it should:
examples: My car always acts up in cold weather.
Her shoulder was acting up (= hurting because of injury).

meanings.definition: to behave badly:
examples: The little girl was acting up, so her mother took her out of the restaurant.

meanings.definition: to operate badly:
examples: My car is acting up again - I don't know what's wrong with it.

meanings.definition: to become active:
examples: Her allergies acted up when she went hiking in the woods.

meanings.definition: said to someone to tell them to stop behaving like someone who is much younger:
examples: Boys, act your age, please!
You need to grow up and act your age!
You're too old for silly pranks like this. I really wish you would just act your age.
Come on, act your age! That food is for eating not for playing with!
Just act your age and apologize to her!

act-do-on-own-responsibility.name: act/do something on your own responsibility

meanings.definition: to act without being told to by someone in authority
to behave in a silly way, often intentionally to make people laugh:
examples: Stop acting the fool, I'm trying to talk to you.
He loves playing the fool.
I'm happy to play the fool if it makes my kids laugh.
He's made his name acting the fool.
I get the impression that he plays the fool a lot in class to make the other kids like him.
He's a bit old to be acting the fool, isn't he?

meanings.definition: to behave in a silly way:
examples: Stop acting the goat!

meanings.definition: to act a part in a film or play with someone as a partner:
examples: Katharine Hepburn played opposite Henry Fonda in many films.
I asked the 23-year-old actor how it felt to act opposite his idol.
Acting opposite Garcia was, she said, a dream come true.
She has twice played opposite her mother.
The sequel sees him playing opposite his real-life wife.
She starred opposite Cruise in his last film.

meanings.definition: a protein found in living cells that is involved in cell movement:
examples: The two proteins that allow muscles to contract are myosin and actin, which operate together.
Contraction is accomplished via interactions between the actin filaments and myosin.

meanings.definition: the job of performing in films or plays:
examples: He wants to get into acting.

meanings.definition: temporarily performing someone else's duties:
examples: Ms. Lopez-Smith will be the acting treasurer.

meanings.definition: doing a job for a short time while the person who usually does that job is not there:
examples: Fisher will serve as acting director while a search is under way to name a permanent director

meanings.definition: someone who does a job for a short time while the person who usually does that job is not there:
examples: He'll be the acting director until they can appoint a permanent one.
Members of the group elected her to serve as acting chair.
He had previously been the acting assistant secretary for secondary education.

meanings.definition: a chemical element that is a soft, silver-white metal and is radioactive:
examples: Researchers are testing the actinium.

meanings.definition: an infection caused by bacteria that produces a hard swelling, especially on the head or neck, or in the lungs:
examples: The bacteria that cause actinomycosis normally live harmlessly in the body.
"Lumpy jaw" is the most common and least severe form of actinomycosis.

meanings.definition: the process of doing something, especially when dealing with a problem or difficulty:
examples: This problem calls for swift/prompt action from the government.
Action to prevent the spread of the disease is high on the government's agenda.
So what's the plan of action? (= What are we going to do?)
The complaints system swings into action (= starts to work) as soon as a claim is made.
We must take action (= do something) to deal with the problem before it spreads to other areas.
The committee was spurred into action (= encouraged to do something) by the threat of government cuts.

meanings.definition: something that you do:
examples: She has to accept the consequences of her actions.
I asked him to explain his actions.

meanings.definition: a physical movement:
examples: I'll say the words and you can mime the actions.
It only needs a small wrist action (= movement of the wrist) to start the process.

meanings.definition: things that are happening, especially exciting or important things:
examples: I like movies with a lot of action.
In her last novel, the action (= the main events) moves between Greece and southern Spain.

meanings.definition: a style of film in which a lot of exciting and often violent things happen:
examples: His filmmaking style blends action, horror, and comedy.
The action genre is often assumed to appeal more to men.

meanings.definition: the effect something has on another thing:
examples: They recorded the action of the drug on the nervous system.

meanings.definition: fighting in a war:
examples: He saw action in the trenches.
Her younger son was killed in action.

meanings.definition: the way something moves or works:
examples: We studied the action of the digestive system.
The car has a very smooth braking action.

meanings.definition: a legal process that is decided in a law court:
examples: She brought an action (for negligence) against the hospital.
The book was halted in South Africa by a threat of legal action.
a libel action
A criminal action was brought against him.

meanings.definition: to do something to deal with a particular problem or matter:
examples: I'll just run through the minutes of the last meeting, raising those points that still have to be actioned.

meanings.definition: the process of doing something, or something done, esp. for a particular purpose:
examples: Quick action in calling the fire department saved many lives.
It was a reckless action which he later came to regret.
We want a leader who will take action to fix our problems.
Financial advisers urged the city to take action (= do something) to deal with the fiscal crisis.

meanings.definition: Action is also fighting in a war:
examples: Her younger son was killed in action.

meanings.definition: In an action film/movie, there is usually a lot of violence and many exciting things happen.
the way something moves or works, or the effect it has on something else:
examples: The heart’s action in regulating blood flow is critically important.

meanings.definition: a process in a court of law to correct a wrong by which a person or group claims to have been hurt:
examples: She brought an action against the hospital for negligence.

meanings.definition: the process of doing something, especially in order to deal with a problem or difficult situation:
examples: The report urged industrialised nations to take further action to cut their budget deficits.
Campaigners say more action is needed on climate change.
Unions are pressing for action on the pay dispute.
decisive/drastic/prompt action
The committee was spurred into action by the threat of government cuts.
You need to clearly outline a specific course of action in your business plan.

meanings.definition: something that you do, especially in order to deal with a problem or difficult situation:
examples: Industry analysts said the company's actions cannot control market prices.
He said that employees must be held accountable for their actions.

meanings.definition: important things that are happening in a market, etc.:
examples: Fund managers let themselves be carried away by the favorable market action of the shares.

meanings.definition: a legal process that is decided in a court of law:
examples: He threatened legal action to recover the property.
The purchaser could have brought an action against the vendor under section 12 of the Sale of Goods Act.

meanings.definition: to do something to deal with a particular task, problem, or plan:
examples: Some of the conclusions and recommendations of the report can be actioned straight away.

meanings.definition: a toy that is made to look like a soldier or a character from a film or television show
a group of people that work together to try to achieve changes relating to a particular situation or in order to help a particular group of people:
examples: Shareholders in Mistral have formed an action group after the company was placed into administration.
a policyholder/shareholder/investor action group

meanings.definition: the hero (= the main character, who is usually good) of a film, television programme, or sometimes a book, who experiences and does a lot of exciting and often violent things, such as fighting against bad people or dangerous creatures:
examples: Arnold Schwarzenegger has played some of the greatest action heroes of all time.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         action point
a training process used by companies and organizations in which employees get into groups to study their own actions and experience in order to help them get better at their job:
examples: The company reinforces formal training with team-based action learning projects.

meanings.definition: a type of film in which a lot of exciting things happen:
examples: He loves action movies - all car chases and jumping out of planes.
People often don't think of "Saving Private Ryan" as an action film.

meanings.definition: a detailed set of instructions to follow in order to solve a problem or achieve something:
examples: develop/draw up/produce an action plan
These are the main recommendations in the 22-point action plan for trade liberalization.

meanings.definition: a job for a particular person or group to do following a meeting, a report, etc.:
examples: This is the list of main action points arising out of the meeting.

meanings.definition: a repeat of an important moment from a sports event shown on television, often more slowly to show the action in detail:
examples: They showed an action replay of the goal.

meanings.definition: the situation in which you are as ready as possible to perform a task you have been preparing for:
examples: The whole school was at action stations for the inspectors' visit.

meanings.definition: a type of film that has an exciting story, often about solving a crime, and in which a lot of exciting things happen:
examples: He created the spectacular special effects seen in two of this year's top action thrillers.
This action thriller is too dependent on action and doesn't have a believable storyline to match.

meanings.definition: willing or likely to take practical action to deal with a problem or situation:
examples: Staff needed to become more creative, action-oriented, and efficient.

meanings.definition: involving practical action to deal with a problem or situation:
examples: an action-oriented agenda/approach
The report needed to be more action-orientated and clearer in its recommendations.

meanings.definition: full of exciting events:
examples: an action-packed thriller/weekend/finale

meanings.definition: full of exciting events:
examples: an action-packed movie

meanings.definition: If something is actionable, it gives someone a good reason for accusing someone in a law court:
examples: She denies that her company has been involved in any actionable activity.

meanings.definition: giving someone a good reason for accusing someone else in a court of law:
examples: His failure to deliver the work would surely be actionable under law as a breach of contract.

meanings.definition: able to be used as a reason for doing something:
examples: actionable information/intelligence

meanings.definition: in a way that gives someone a good reason for accusing someone in a law court:
examples: She had accused him, possibly actionably, of having stolen the idea from one of his students.
The website contained material that was actionably obscene and defamatory.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         action
to do something to deal with a particular problem or matter:
examples: I'll just run through the minutes of the last meeting, raising those points that still have to be actioned.

meanings.definition: a type of film in which a lot of exciting things happen:
examples: Wahlberg plays a former Marine sniper in the actioner "Shooter".
This race-against-time actioner has had mixed reviews.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         action
to do something to deal with a particular problem or matter:
examples: I'll just run through the minutes of the last meeting, raising those points that still have to be actioned.

meanings.definition: said to emphasize that what you do is more important and shows your intentions and feelings more clearly than what you say
what you do is more important than what you say, because the things you do show your true intentions and feelings:
examples: Team USA is not expected to win, but they believe actions speak louder than words.

meanings.definition: to cause something to start:
examples: The alarm is activated by the lightest pressure.

meanings.definition: to make a chemical reaction happen more quickly, especially by heating
to cause something to start working:
examples: Something activated the car alarm.

meanings.definition: In sports, to activate a player is to bring that player back to the regular team after an injury.
to make something start working or happening:
examples: New customers must call an automated line to activate their card.
The move will activate a clause in the contract which gives the company the option to sell or demand the outstanding £3.5m owed on the deal.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         activate
to cause something to start:
examples: The alarm is activated by the lightest pressure.

meanings.definition: to make a chemical reaction happen more quickly, especially by heating

a type of charcoal (= a hard, black substance similar to coal) that has been treated so that other substances stick to it. It is used to clean unwanted substances from air or water, and as a medicine. :
examples: Filter tap water through activated charcoal to remove pollutants.
Activated charcoal is an extremely effective remedy for nearly all poisonings.

meanings.definition: sewage (= waste matter such as water and human waste) that goes through a process using oxygen to encourage bacteria to break down the waste. This is then added to new sewage to help it break down more quickly:
examples: Activated sludge uses microorganisms to break down organic matter in wastewater.
The sewage works is a conventionally laid-out, activated sludge plant.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         activate
to cause something to start:
examples: The alarm is activated by the lightest pressure.

meanings.definition: to make a chemical reaction happen more quickly, especially by heating
the act of making something start or making it start working:
examples: The false activation of an alarm is a serious matter.
You will be sent an account activation email.

meanings.definition: busy with a particular activity:
examples: He is 90 years old, but remains active in the local community.
The goal of our organization is to make sure that people stay active.
You have to try to keep active as you grow older.
physically/mentally active

meanings.definition: involved in a particular activity:
examples: She's very active in (= involved in) local politics.
Enemy forces remain active in the mountainous areas around the city.
Both of his parents were very politically active.
It is important to educate children before they become sexually active.
He takes an active role in the team nowadays.
The family plays an active role in the local community.
She's an active member of her trade union (= not only belongs to it, but does work to help it).

meanings.definition: An active volcano is one that might erupt (= throw out hot liquid rock or other matter) at any time.
An active verb or sentence is one in which the subject is the person or thing that performs the stated action:
examples: "Catrin told me" is an active sentence, and "I was told by Catrin" is passive.

meanings.definition: doing something as you usually do, or being able to do something physically or mentally:
examples: He was still an active runner at 55.
She’s active in state politics (= involved in it).
She intends to remain politically active.
His National Guard unit was put on active duty (= made part of the regular fighting force).

meanings.definition: An active volcano is one that might begin to throw out hot gases, liquid, or rocks at any time.
describing a verb or sentence in which the subject is the person or thing that does what is stated:
examples: In "Alex gave me a gift," the verb "give" is active, and in "I was given a gift by Alex," "give" is passive.

meanings.definition: busy with or involved in a particular activity:
examples: He expects to remain active in commodity trading in London.
She claims to be active in almost every aspect of her business.

meanings.definition: doing something practical rather than allowing a situation to develop by itself:
examples: He has been an active member of the Executive Committee since 2004.
Employees who take an active part in the project feel more involved and more responsible about the results.
active participation/intervention
We would expect countries whose firms are highly globalized to be more active in adopting e-commerce.

meanings.definition: involving a lot of buying and selling of shares, etc.:
examples: Trading was most active in five-year maturities.
The session was active early, but volume dropped off after midday.
This made Intel the second-most active stock in U.S. trading.

meanings.definition: used to describe a company that is selling goods and services or doing business, especially in a particular place:
examples: Whitbread was especially active but several other brewers were also buying at the rate of 20 or 30 a year.
The company is active in a wide range of businesses, including oil, chemicals, and construction.
Over the last ten years, the company has become active in Europe.

meanings.definition: working or being used at a particular time:
examples: The company has more than one million active cardholders, with about 44% of all group sales being made through the card.
active employees/members
The organization releases a weekly survey of the number of active oil and gas drilling rigs in the U.S. and Canada.

meanings.definition: relating to programs, etc. that are being used at a particular time:
examples: Click the associated tab in a bar running across the screen, and the selected page opens in the active window.

meanings.definition: a bond that is traded regularly, especially on the New York Stock Exchange
a person who is interested in and involved in social and political issues and activities in their country or community:
examples: The programme aims to teach students the importance of being active citizens in society.
People should be active citizens, involved in their local community.

meanings.definition: the fact that people are interested in and involved in social and political issues and activities in their country or community:
examples: This is an opportunity to contribute to the community, to focus on volunteering and active citizenship.
Events such as these enable students to be conscious of the society around them and promote active citizenship.

meanings.definition: ACE
the situation in which the body produces its own antibodies (= substances in the blood that fight disease)
On an active matrix display (= screen), each pixel (= the smallest unit of an image) is controlled separately to create a very clear image:
examples: The machine uses a wide active matrix display to increase viewing angles.
It is the same technology used in active matrix screens of notebook computers.

meanings.definition: a senior person who owns a company with other people and does practical work relating to running the company
the people in a country or area who normally work and earn money:
examples: Equality of opportunity must be secured in order to realize the productive potential of the whole active population.

meanings.definition: the process of doing gentle exercises to help your body to feel better after a period of physical exercise:
examples: Active recovery is a really important part of successful training.
Begin your active recovery as soon as the exercise session finishes.

meanings.definition: the use of actions, sometimes including violence, to show that you oppose something:
examples: The artists want to build public opinion and organize more active resistance to attempts to limit their right to work freely.
The greatest threat to the military regime is the increasing appeal of active resistance in the country.

meanings.definition: shares in a particular company that are traded regularly on a stock market:
examples: It was the fourth-most active stock on U.S. exchanges.

meanings.definition: a way of treating a medical condition that involves a period of waiting and regular testing, rather than immediate treatment such as surgery or chemotherapy
a time when a lot of shares, etc. are being bought and sold on the stock market:
examples: The shares raced ahead in active trading to close at 230p.

meanings.definition: a trust (= arrangement of legal control over someone's money or property) where the trustee (= person who has this control) has other particular duties, such as investing money, or passing on profits, rents, etc.
in a way that involves positive action:
examples: He's very actively involved in (= does a lot of work for) the local party.
It's nice having a man who actively encourages me to spend money.
I've been actively looking for a job for six months.

meanings.definition: clothes that are worn for sports or other physical activities:
examples: Women's activewear is becoming an important sector of the fashion industry.

meanings.definition: the use of direct and noticeable action to achieve a result, usually a political or social one:
examples: black/student activism
The levels of political activism in this country have greatly declined.

meanings.definition: the use of direct and public methods to try to bring about esp. social and political changes that you and others want:
examples: political/social activism

meanings.definition: a person who believes strongly in political or social change and takes part in activities such as public protests to try to make this happen:
examples: He's been a trade union/party activist for many years.
an animal rights activist

meanings.definition: the situation in which a lot of things are happening or people are moving around:
examples: Economists are concerned by the low level of economic activity.
Experts predict that this could depress business activity for years.
There was a sudden flurry of activity when the director walked in.
There was a lot of activity in preparation for the Queen's visit.

meanings.definition: the work of a group or organization to achieve an aim:
examples: He was found guilty of terrorist activity.
criminal activities

meanings.definition: something that is done for enjoyment, especially an organized event:
examples: His spare-time activities include cooking, tennis, and windsurfing.
We offer our guests a wide range of outdoor/sporting activities.

meanings.definition: the doing of something, or something that you are doing, have done, or could do:
examples: There were lots of activities for children at the museum.
Her favorite activity is visiting antique shops.
Carbon dioxide is also produced by human activity.

meanings.definition: a situation in which a lot of things are happening or being done:
examples: Any conflict has the potential to disrupt business activity.
manufacturing/marketing/trading activity
This package of tax cuts and spending increases is designed to boost economic activity over the next year.
The increased level of activity in our principal markets flattened out during the first half of this year.

meanings.definition: the work of a person, group, or organization to achieve something, especially to make money:
examples: The company's activities stretch from Australia to the US.
We invest primarily in companies which have their principal business activities in the Pacific Basin.
manufacturing/marketing/management activities

meanings.definition: a holiday in which you can do a lot of sports and other activities

→ 
        
         work sampling
someone who pretends to be someone else while performing in a film, play, or television or radio programme:
examples: "Who's your favourite actor?" "Robert de Niro."
She is one of the most versatile actors working today.

meanings.definition: a person or an organization that is involved in or important in politics, society, etc. in some way because of their actions:
examples: International law recognizes that a state can engage in armed conflict against a non-state actor.
The country will find itself as one of the key actors on the world stage.
The miners, through their trades unions, have long been major actors in the political arena .

meanings.definition: a person who plays the part of a character in a movie or play:
examples: The play has a cast of six actors.

meanings.definition: a woman who pretends to be someone else while performing in a film, play, or television programme:
examples: She's the highest-paid actress in Hollywood.

meanings.definition: existing in fact:
examples: We had estimated about 300 visitors, but the actual number was much higher.
The exams are in July, but the actual results (= the results themselves) don't appear until September.

meanings.definition: real; existing in fact:
examples: We expected 50 people, but the actual number was a lot higher.

meanings.definition: true or exact:
examples: Residents are paying electricity prices that are double the actual cost of generating electricity.
There is a gap between desired and actual performance.
actual sales/results

meanings.definition: real, rather than part of an idea or plan:
examples: He's had a lot of interviews, but never had an actual job.

meanings.definition: real, not on the internet:
examples: The actual stores offer local convenience while the virtual stores offer variety for shoppers.

meanings.definition: an amount of money that a company really spends, rather than an amount of money that it plans or expects to spend:
examples: We continuously compare budgeted amounts with actuals.

meanings.definition: something that physically exists such as oil, metal, grain, or coffee that is traded on the stock market:
examples: Transactions can be trade in actuals or by means of futures contracts.

meanings.definition: in the UK and some other countries, the crime of hurting someone physically in a way that may not be serious or cause permanent damage, but that does cause injury or pain:
examples: He admitted three offences of assault causing actual bodily harm.
In court, the two teenagers denied actual bodily harm.

meanings.definition: the amount of money that a court orders to be paid to someone in return for something that has been lost or damaged:
examples: The jury originally awarded actual damages of $2.5 million in the case and $22.5 million in punitive damages.

meanings.definition: the money that is lost when something is sold, because it has gone down in value, or when costs and the effects of inflation are included:
examples: I'll hold at the moment, because it's too much of an actual loss if I sell now.

meanings.definition: the money that is lost or will be lost as a result of something, which can be calculated and clearly shown:
examples: The High Court sought to make the final damages reflect Mr Smith's actual loss.

meanings.definition: the price of a commodity (= a product such as oil, metal, grain, or coffee) that can be sold and delivered immediately:
examples: To see the actual price of gold you have to look at what dealers are charging.

meanings.definition: the price of something when costs such as taxes, interest, etc. are included:
examples: Leasing is a complicated option, and dealers in most states don't have to tell you the actual price you are paying for the car.

meanings.definition: a situation in which insured property is totally destroyed, lost, or made useless, and the insurance company pays the maximum amount:
examples: They claimed that the capture and removal of the ship to Somali waters constituted an actual total loss under the Marine Insurance Act.

meanings.definition: a fact:
examples: He's out of touch with the actualities of life in Africa.

meanings.definition: to make something that could possibly happen or be achieved really happen or be achieved:
examples: the techniques that athletes use to actualize their potential

meanings.definition: in fact or really:
examples: I didn't actually see her - I just heard her voice.
So what actually happened?

meanings.definition: used in sentences in which there is information that is in some way surprising or the opposite of what most people would expect:
examples: I didn't like him at first, but in the end I actually got quite fond of him.
I'm one of the few people who doesn't actually like champagne.
Don't tell me he actually paid for you!

meanings.definition: used as a way of making a sentence slightly more polite, for example when you are expressing an opposing opinion, correcting what someone else has said, or refusing an offer:
examples: "Alexander looks like he'd be good at sports." "Actually, he's not."
Actually, Gavin, it was Tuesday of last week, not Wednesday.
"Do you mind if I smoke?" "Well, actually, I'd rather you didn't."

meanings.definition: used to say that something is true, esp. when the true situation may not be known:
examples: We actually had a hard time moving the sofa.

meanings.definition: Actually is often used when you want to emphasize that something is surprising or unusual:
examples: He actually expected me to pay for his dinner.

meanings.definition: relating to the work of an actuary, or to the job of being an actuary:
examples: These figures are based on actuarial calculations of the risks involved.
actuarial jobs

meanings.definition: relating to calculations of risk for insurance companies and pension funds, especially calculations of the age to which people are expected to live. The companies and funds use the results to make certain that they always have enough money to make payments to the people who have a right to them:
examples: Companies currently use actuarial assumptions to determine whether their pension fund shows a surplus or a deficit.
an actuarial calculation/assessment/evaluation

meanings.definition: relating to the job of being an actuary:
examples: The debate is dividing the actuarial profession.
an actuarial adviser/consultant
an actuarial firm/consultancy
actuarial work/advice/skills

meanings.definition: the risk that the calculations done by an actuary may be wrong and an insurance company or pension fund will lose money:
examples: Closing the pension scheme to new entrants would not save the company money in the short term, but it would reduce actuarial risk.

meanings.definition: a person who calculates how likely accidents, such as fire, flood, or loss of property, are to happen, and tells insurance companies how much they should charge their customers

a person whose job is to calculate risk for insurance companies and pension funds, especially the age to which people are expected to live. The companies and funds use the results to make certain that they always have enough money to make payments to the people who have a right to them:
examples: Actuaries and auditors have a statutory duty to report anything that exposes the assets of a pension scheme to risk.

meanings.definition: to make a machine work or be the reason a person acts in a certain way:
examples: A detonator is actuated by heat, percussion, friction, or electricity.
He was actuated almost entirely by altruism.

         actuate
to make a machine work or be the reason a person acts in a certain way:
examples: A detonator is actuated by heat, percussion, friction, or electricity.

to make a machine work or be the reason a person acts in a certain way:
examples: A detonator is actuated by heat, percussion, friction, or electricity.

meanings.definition: the fact of making a machine start to work or a process start to happen:

meanings.definition: part of a machine or system that moves something or makes something work:
examples: the cruise control actuator
The actuators are powered by wires and controlled by three circuits connected to a power supply.

meanings.definition: the ability to hear, see, or think accurately and clearly:
examples: Tiredness also affects visual acuity.
He was a man of great political acuity.

meanings.definition: skill in making correct decisions and judgments in a particular subject, such as business or politics:
examples: She has considerable business/financial acumen.

meanings.definition: the ability to make correct judgments:
examples: Mr. Estavez has real business acumen.

meanings.definition: skill in making correct decisions and judgments in business or in a particular area of business:
examples: He is an astute man with sound business acumen.
commercial/financial/legal acumen

meanings.definition: a treatment for pain or illness in which certain parts of the body are pressed with the hands
a treatment for pain or illness in which thin needles are positioned just under the surface of the skin at special points around the body:
examples: Acupuncture originated in China.

meanings.definition: a treatment for pain and illness in which special needles are put into the skin at particular positions
a person who is trained to do acupuncture (= a treatment for pain or illness using thin needles put into the skin in particular places around the body):
examples: Acupuncture is an extremely safe treatment if done by a certified acupuncturist.
She was managing her asthma with help from an acupuncturist.

meanings.definition: If a bad situation is acute, it causes severe problems or damage:
examples: She felt acute embarrassment/anxiety/concern at his behaviour.
The problem of poverty is particularly acute in rural areas.

meanings.definition: An acute pain or illness is one that quickly becomes very severe:
examples: acute abdominal pains
an acute attack of appendicitis

meanings.definition: used to describe intelligence, senses, etc. that are very good, accurate, and able to notice very small differences:
examples: acute eyesight/hearing
an acute sense of smell
a woman of acute intelligence/judgment

meanings.definition: An acute angle is less than 90 degrees.
a sign that is written above a letter in some languages, showing you how to pronounce the letter:
examples: There's an acute accent on the e in "café".

meanings.definition: very serious, extreme, or severe:
examples: The area has an acute water shortage.

meanings.definition: In medicine, acute describes severe conditions, illnesses, or injuries that need immediate care:
examples: Not all hospitals can provide acute care.

meanings.definition: aware of or able to recognize small differences between things, or being accurate in judging something:
examples: He has very acute hearing.

meanings.definition: (of an angle) less than 90º
if a bad situation is acute, it causes severe problems or damage:
examples: The problem is particularly acute for small businesses.
an acute conflict/crisis/need

meanings.definition: completely or extremely:
examples: Management is acutely aware of the resentment that their decision may cause.
Another scandal would be acutely embarrassing for the government.

meanings.definition: in a very clever or detailed way:
examples: She acutely identified all the main problems.

meanings.definition: the quality of being very good, accurate, and showing an ability to notice very small differences:
examples: He is remembered for the acuteness of his intellect.
He was distinguished by the liveliness of his conversation and the acuteness of his understanding.

meanings.definition: the fact of being very serious or severe:
examples: The choice of drug depends upon the severity, acuteness and cause of the pain.
You will have to deal with crises of varying acuteness.

meanings.definition: informal for an advertisement:
examples: I often prefer the ads on TV to the actual programmes.

meanings.definition:

examples: in 1215 AD/AD 1215
during the seventh century AD

abbreviation for

abbreviation for Anno Domini (= in the year of the Lord), used to show that a year is after the year in which Jesus Christ is thought to have been born:
examples: the 12th century A.D.
The Roman empire ended in A.D. 476.

meanings.definition: an advertisement:
examples: He appeared in an ad for fizzy drinks.
They took out a full-page ad in the newspaper.
The company has been running ads on Spanish-language TV network Telemundo.
newspaper/television/internet ads

meanings.definition: advertising:
examples: Who created the concept for the ad campaign?
ad executives
ad revenue/spending/budget

meanings.definition: a company that produces advertisements

→ 
        
         advertising agency
a computer program that prevents advertisements from being displayed on a screen, for example when you visit a website:
examples: Many users have an ad blocker installed.

meanings.definition: the use of a computer program to prevent advertisements from being displayed on a screen, for example when you visit a website:
examples: Ad blocking poses a threat to the revenue of many websites.
ad-blocking software

meanings.definition: made or happening only for a particular purpose or need, not planned before it happens:
examples: We deal with problems on an ad hoc basis (= as they happen).
an ad hoc committee/meeting

meanings.definition: for a particular purpose or need, esp. for an immediate need:
examples: The ad hoc committee will meet next week.
Unfortunately, we deal with problems ad hoc.

meanings.definition: happening or existing only for a particular purpose and not previously planned:
examples: Cooperation is often on an ad hoc basis and relies on personal contacts between individuals.
an ad hoc committee

meanings.definition: the practice of reacting to what happens or is needed at a particular time, rather than planning in advance:
examples: He offers a rigid set of foreign policy principles in sharp contrast to the previous leader's ad hocism.

meanings.definition: the practice of reacting to what happens or is needed at a particular time, rather than planning in a way that suits all possible situations:
examples: The government cannot continue to get away with ad hockery in response to local transport needs.

meanings.definition: (of a criticism, etc.) directed against a person, rather than against what that person says:
examples: an ad hominem attack on his rival
I'm not going to be swayed by ad hominem arguments attacking me instead of supporting your own position.

meanings.definition: in a way that is directed against a person, rather than against what they say:
examples: She knows how to debate ideas without engaging in argument ad hominem.

meanings.definition: criticism or attacks directed against a person, rather than against what they say:
examples: He never resorts to ad hominem.
Her speech contained ad hominem after ad hominem.

meanings.definition: for ever, without ending:
examples: "Why was she such a lousy boss?" "Oh, because she was unreasonable, disrespectful, rude, inconsiderate - I could go on ad infinitum."

meanings.definition: said without any preparation or practice:
examples: I'd forgotten the notes for my speech so I had to do it ad lib.

meanings.definition: to speak in public without having planned what to say:
examples: She ad-libbed her way through the entire speech.

meanings.definition: to do something without preparation or planning:
examples: She had lost her notes, so she ad-libbed for ten minutes.

meanings.definition: used to refer to someone chosen by a law court to do something for another person when that person is not able to do it themselves. Ad litem is Latin for 'for this action':
examples: A guardian ad litem is normally appointed in cases where children are involved.

meanings.definition: If someone discusses something ad nauseam, they talk about it so much that it becomes very boring:
examples: He talks ad nauseam about how clever his children are.

meanings.definition: an ad valorem payment, rate, or tax is calculated according to the price of a product or service, rather than at a fixed rate:
examples: Companies receive subsidies in the form of simple ad valorem payments based on the size of their export sales.
We think an ad valorem tax is the best because every time the price goes up the tax goes up.
Some would say that imposing an ad valorum tariff would be likely to be inflationary.

not containing any advertising:
examples: an ad-free search engine

abbreviation for the Americans with Disabilities Act: a US law that protects the rights of people who have disabilities (= injuries, illnesses, etc. that make it difficult for them to do the things that other people do):
examples: Information about ADA compliance is available online at www.ada.gov.

meanings.definition: a wise saying:
examples: He remembered the old adage "Look before you leap".

meanings.definition: a wise saying or proverb:
examples: He remembered the old adage, "Look before you leap."

meanings.definition: a piece of music that should be played slowly:
examples: Barber's Adagio for Strings

meanings.definition: a character in the Bible who was the first man made by God
the part of your throat that sticks out, especially in men, and moves up and down when you speak or swallow
the front part of the neck that sticks out, esp. in a man, and moves up and down when you speak or swallow
a type of orchid (= a plant with unusually shaped flowers) that grows in North America and has yellow flowers that are purple at the end, and a single leaf with thin pale stripes on it:
examples: Adam-and-eve grows from a tuber, or corm, that spreads underground.
Another name for adam and eve is the putty root because of the sticky fluid that comes out of the corms when crushed.
The Adam and Eve grows best in moist shade.

meanings.definition: the quality of being impossible to persuade, or unwilling to change an opinion or decision:
examples: A spokesperson denied that the president's adamancy had caused a chill in relations between the two countries.
Despite her earlier adamancy that she would see no one, she allowed us in.

meanings.definition: impossible to persuade, or unwilling to change an opinion or decision:
examples: I've told her she should stay at home and rest but she's adamant that she's coming.

meanings.definition: unwilling to be persuaded to change an opinion or decision:
examples: She was adamant about becoming a dancer.

meanings.definition: extremely hard:
examples: a wall of adamantine rock

meanings.definition: extremely determined and strong or unwilling to change:
examples: He bowed to her adamantine will.

meanings.definition: in a way that means it is impossible to persuade you or make you change your opinion or decision:
examples: The mayor is adamantly opposed to any tax increase.
Most people were adamantly against the decision.

meanings.definition: to change, or to change something, to suit different conditions or uses:
examples: Davies is busy adapting Brinkworth's latest novel for television.
The play had been adapted for (= changed to make it suitable for) children.
The recipe here is a pork roast adapted from Caroline O'Neill's book "Louisiana Kitchen".
Many software companies have adapted popular programs to the new operating system.
We had to adapt our plans to fit Jack's timetable.

meanings.definition: to change your ideas or behaviour to make them suitable for a new situation:
examples: The good thing about children is that they adapt very easily to new environments.
It took me a while to adapt to the new job.

meanings.definition: If a living thing adapts, it changes slightly over time so it can continue to exist in a particular environment:
examples: Species have adapted to climate changes throughout history.
The ways in which organisms have adapted to survive in this extreme environment are not well understood.

meanings.definition: to adjust to different conditions or uses, or to change to meet different situations
to become familiar with a new situation:
examples: To remain competitive the company has to be able to adapt to the changing marketplace.
Dick has adapted very well to running a multinational.

meanings.definition: to change something to suit different conditions or uses:
examples: Sometimes you have to adapt the design to suit the customer's requirements.
It was the first time a British brewer had adapted a product for French tastes.

meanings.definition: to change something such as a book to make it suitable for a different purpose or for different people:
examples: Davies is busy adapting Brinkworth's latest novel for television.
The sitcom is currently being adapted for American audiences.

meanings.definition: an ability or willingness to change in order to suit different conditions:
examples: Adaptability is a necessary quality in an ever-changing work environment.
Overseas experience shows adaptability and an ability to cope with foreign languages.

meanings.definition: ability or willingness to change:
examples: This car is the perfect mix of comfort, adaptability, and speed.

meanings.definition: able or willing to change in order to suit different conditions:
examples: The survivors in this life seem to be those who are adaptable to change.

meanings.definition: able or willing to change:
examples: He’s pretty adaptable, and change doesn’t bother him.

meanings.definition: the process of changing to suit different conditions:
examples: The documentary is about corruption, crime and human adaptation to difficult circumstances.
His team's successful adaptation to life in the top-flight has come as no surprise.

meanings.definition: the process in which a living thing changes slightly over time to be able to continue to exist in a particular environment, or a change like this:
examples: Evolution occurs as a result of adaptation to new environments.
It's these evolutionary adaptations that make aphids and other insects so destructive.

meanings.definition: a film, book, play, etc. that has been made from another film, book, play, etc.:
examples: Last year he starred in the film adaptation of Bill Cronshaw's best-selling novel.

meanings.definition: something produced to adjust to different conditions or uses, or to meet different situations:
examples: The movie was an adaptation of a novel.

meanings.definition: a characteristic of a plant or animal that makes it able to adjust to the conditions of a particular environment
changed slightly for a particular purpose or use:
examples: He drives a specially adapted car.
The festive grotto is in fact an adapted garden shed.

meanings.definition: (of a living thing) able to exist in a particular environment because of changes that have happened to it over time:
examples: Both trees are well adapted to London's dry climate and dirty air.
The rat is uniquely adapted to living around humans.

meanings.definition: a type of plug that makes it possible to connect two or more pieces of equipment to the same electrical supply
a device that is used to connect two pieces of equipment
a person who makes slight changes to a book, play, or other piece of text so that it can be performed

examples: A plant physiologist, she observes the capacity of plants for adaptive behaviour.

meanings.definition: able to adjust:

meanings.definition: able to adjust to the conditions of a particular environment
changing quickly to suit different conditions:

meanings.definition: the way in which living things change and develop over many years to be able to live in a particular place:
examples: Ecological variation is a vital determinant of the adaptive evolution of timing of seed germination.

meanings.definition: a method of education or training using computers, that uses algorithms (= sets of mathematical rules) to change teaching material, exercises, etc. according to the needs and performance of each learner:
examples: Adaptive learning is very powerful as it allows a custom-made learning experience.

meanings.definition: in a way that involves changing to suit changing conditions:
examples: There are health apps that adaptively tweak an exercise regimen to maximize the benefit to each user.

meanings.definition: the quality of being able to change to suit different conditions:
examples: Flexibility and adaptiveness are important qualities in managers.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Asian Development Bank: a bank that helps social and economic progress in Asian countries
