to put two or more numbers or amounts together to get a total:
examples: It's $45 - $50 if you add in the cost of postage.
Don't forget to add on your travelling expenses.
We'll keep a running subtotal and add the tax on at the end.
If you add (= calculate the total of) three and four you get seven.

meanings.definition: to put something with something else to increase the number or amount or to improve the whole:
examples: She's added a Picasso to her collection.
Beat the butter and sugar together and slowly add the eggs.
Her colleagues' laughter only added to her embarrassment.

meanings.definition: to say another thing:
examples: She was sad, she said, but added (= said also) that she felt she had made the right decision.
"Oh, and thank you for all your help!" he added as he was leaving.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Attention Deficit Disorder: a name used mainly in the 1980s for a condition in which someone, especially a child, is often in a state of activity or excitement and unable to direct their attention towards what they are doing:
examples: A person with ADHD, previously known as ADD (attention-deficit disorder), has trouble focusing on activities, organizing and finishing tasks, and following instructions.
She said her child's teacher thought he might have ADD.

meanings.definition: to put something with something else to increase the number or amount or to make it more important:
examples: Beat the butter and sugar together, and then add the eggs.
"Thanks for all your help!" he added as he was leaving.
Factors beyond their control added to their success.

meanings.definition: to calculate the total of a group of numbers:
examples: If you add three and four you get seven.

meanings.definition: to put something with something else in order to improve it or increase the number or amount:
examples: Investors can add more money to the fund at any time.
You can add a link to your own website.

meanings.definition: to put one number or amount with another in order to calculate a total:
examples: You have to add the cost of postage to the subtotal.
So when you add all those figures together, that is where 534 comes from.

meanings.definition: to increase in value by a particular amount, or to make something increase in value by a particular amount:
examples: Today its shares added 7p to 460p.

meanings.definition: to calculate the total of two or more numbers:
examples: If you add those four figures up, it comes to over £1,500.
She added the bill up.
I'm not very good at adding up!

meanings.definition: to increase gradually until there is a large amount:
examples: The changes in air quality are small, but after a while they do add up and affect people's health.

meanings.definition: to seem reasonable or likely:
examples: Watson claimed he was at home at the time of the murder, but police said his story didn't add up.

meanings.definition: to calculate the total of two or more numbers:
examples: We added up the cost of everything we wanted to buy and divided the total between us.

meanings.definition: to calculate the total of two or more prices, numbers, etc.:
examples: He quickly added up the figures in his head.

meanings.definition: to gradually increase until there is a large total:
examples: The fees were adding up.

meanings.definition: to make it more likely that something is true:
examples: This newly discovered account adds credence to the story.
We have not seen anything that would add credence to allegations of election fraud.

meanings.definition: to make an argument or bad situation worse:
examples: The discovery that the government was aware of the cover-up has really added fuel to the fire.

meanings.definition: to make a bad situation worse:
examples: The President said he wouldn’t add fuel to the fire by commenting without knowing all the facts.
I was late and, to add insult to injury, forgot my keys.

meanings.definition: to include or build something extra:
examples: We’ve added on a couple of rooms to the house.
You will need a different kind of building permit if you are adding on to the existing structure.
It was an old house that had been added on to.
We'll add on a second bathroom as soon as we have the money.

meanings.definition: a piece of equipment that can be connected to a computer to give it an extra use:
examples: A printer is a useful add-on.

meanings.definition: an extra part that is added, especially to an officially organized plan, system, agreement, etc.:
examples: Legal expenses cover is often sold as an add-on to household insurance policies.

meanings.definition: to add an extra amount to a total, or an extra item to a list:
examples: Don't forget to add on your travelling expenses.
If you like something that's not on the list then add it on!
All team players in the videogame should stop playing while your team captain adds on new items or powers.
It is completely unacceptable for firms to add on the cost of insurance which the customer has not asked for.

meanings.definition: to include or build something extra:
examples: We’ve added on a couple of rooms to the house.

meanings.definition: to include an extra thing or amount:
examples: When you add on the amount you have to spend to earn Air Miles, the savings are dubious.

meanings.definition: to build an extra part on a building:
examples: Developers want to improve the site or add on.

meanings.definition: something extra that is added to a product to make it better:
examples: DVDs often include bonus endings and other add-ons.

add-on parts/products/services

meanings.definition: a piece of computer equipment or software that is added to a computer so that the computer can do more or different things:
examples: It would require an add-on to a browser to make it all work.
add-on devices/features/software

meanings.definition: extra:
examples: Car dealers profit from questionable add-on charges, such as for extended warranties.

meanings.definition: If you add salt to a subject or conversation, you make it more interesting:
examples: You can be sure she'll always add salt to the conversation!

meanings.definition: to include something as part of something else :
examples: It's £45 - £50 if you add in the cost of postage.
You can add mushrooms in with the leeks, carrots, and celery for a richer soup.

meanings.definition: to include something as part of something else:
examples: A loan for $100 could carry annual interest rates of 50% once fees are added in.

meanings.definition: to increase something, especially something bad or unpleasant:
examples: Her colleagues' laughter only added to her embarrassment.
Price rises for basic foodstuffs added to the upward pressure on inflation.

meanings.definition: to become a particular amount:
examples: The various building programmes add up to several thousand new homes.
We thought we'd bought lots of food, but it didn't add up to much when we'd spread it out on the table.

meanings.definition: to have a particular result or effect:
examples: It all added up to a lot of hard work for all of us.
Their proposals do not add up to any real help for the poor.

meanings.definition: to result in something:
examples: The details don't add up to a complete picture of what caused the explosion.

meanings.definition: to make a particular total:
examples: The numbers in each row add up to 25.

meanings.definition: to make a particular amount:
examples: The company's assets add up to $107bn.

meanings.definition: to have a particular effect or result:
examples: These changes could add up to a marked improvement for the library.

meanings.definition: interest that is added to the principal (= original amount) of a loan. The loan payments are equal to the interest added to the original amount divided by the number of months of the loan.

meanings.definition: an improvement or addition to something that makes it worth more:
examples: The printer's added value makes it worth the extra cost.

meanings.definition: involving an improvement or addition to something that makes it worth more:
examples: The department store emphasized added-value benefits such as its loyalty scheme.

meanings.definition: an increase in the value of a resource, product, or service as the result of a particular process:
examples: They want as much of the added value as possible from their exploited natural resources to benefit their own economy.
added-value products/services

meanings.definition: something useful that someone can give to a company, especially something that helps the company make more money:
examples: The key to the job search is to offer added value and communicate clearly.
added-value skills

a gambling addict

meanings.definition: a person who is unable to stop doing or using something
unable to stop taking drugs, or doing something as a habit:
examples: By the age of 14 he was addicted to heroin.

meanings.definition: an inability to stop doing or using something, especially something harmful:
examples: He developed an addiction to painkillers.

many of the prison inmates had drug or alcohol addictions.

For people with OCD, cleaning can become an addiction.

meanings.definition: the need or strong desire to do or to have something, or a very strong liking for something:
examples: His addiction began with prescription drugs.
I have an addiction to mystery stories.

meanings.definition: An addictive drug is one that you cannot stop taking once you have started:
examples: Tobacco is highly addictive.

meanings.definition: An addictive activity or food is one that you cannot stop doing or eating once you have started:
examples: The problem with video games is that they're addictive.
These nuts are addictive - I can't stop eating them.

meanings.definition: a set of characteristics that mean that you very quickly become addicted to drugs, food, alcohol, etc.:
examples: He's got an addictive personality.
I would probably describe myself as having an addictive personality.
For an addictive personality, credit cards can represent a dangerous temptation.

meanings.definition: the fact that you cannot stop taking a drug, doing an activity, etc. once you have started it:
examples: Were the tobacco companies guilty of lying to the public about the addictiveness of smoking?
Ritalin is a "controlled substance" because of its potential for addictiveness.

meanings.definition: a severe disease in which the adrenal glands (= small organs just above the kidneys) do not produce enough of two hormones and that can cause brown spots on the skin, muscle weakness, and tiredness:
examples: The major cause of Addison's disease is an autoimmune reaction.

meanings.definition: someone new who has joined or been added to a group:

meanings.definition: the act of adding a substance or thing to something else:

meanings.definition: something extra that is added to something:

meanings.definition: resulting in a reduction in the amount of carbon dioxide gas that is released into the environment, which would not have happened without trading carbon credits:
examples: Would the project have been implemented, even without the sales of the carbon offsets? If the answer is yes, the project is not “additional.”

meanings.definition: an amount of money that a court orders to be paid to someone in addition to an amount it has already ordered to be paid:
examples: If negligence is proven, however, some additional damages can be sought.

meanings.definition: the situation in which a government or organization is able to get money for a project from another government or organization, especially the European Union, only if it pays for most of the project itself:
examples: The principle of 'additionality', decrees that money should go only to projects that would not have gone ahead with normal public sector funding.

meanings.definition: the reduction in the amount of carbon dioxide gas released into the environment that happens only as a result of trading carbon credits:
examples: The buzzword in the industry is "additionality" - the idea that offset purchases lead to additional greenhouse gas reductions.

meanings.definition: also or in addition:

meanings.definition: also:

meanings.definition: the ability to become more familiar with a new situation:

meanings.definition: the process of becoming more familiar with a new situation:

meanings.definition: the job of getting information about an accident, theft, etc. in order to decide how much money to pay an insurance customer:

meanings.definition: the amount of money that an insurance company pays to a customer who has been involved in an accident, had something stolen, etc.:

meanings.definition: an account kept by a company in addition to the official account, that is used to check that the official account is correct

meanings.definition: to control the operation or arrangement of something:

meanings.definition: the process that takes place when a company cannot pay its debts and is allowed to make changes to its organization to try to avoid going into liquidation (= when a business is closed and the things it owns are sold):

meanings.definition: the management or control of an organization:

meanings.definition: the government of the United States or of some other countries:

meanings.definition: relating to the arrangements and work that is needed to control the operation of a plan or organization:

meanings.definition: relating to the laws that control local government:

meanings.definition: relating to the work of managing or organizing a business or business activity:

meanings.definition: a period of time when an employee does not have to go to work for a particular reason:
examples: Managers and supervisors are authorized to approve paid administrative leave for individuals in their areas who were affected by the fire.

meanings.definition: a period of time when you are absent from your job for a special reason:

meanings.definition: relating to the arrangements and work that is needed to control the operation of a plan or organization:

meanings.definition: according to the way something is managed or organized:

meanings.definition: someone whose job is to control the operation of a business, organization, or plan:

meanings.definition: a person chosen by a court to manage a company that cannot pay its debts in order to try to improve its financial situation and to keep it operating:

meanings.definition: deserving respect or approval:

meanings.definition: very well, or in a way that is admirable (= deserving respect or approval):

meanings.definition: an officer of very high rank in the navy:

meanings.definition: a naval officer of the highest rank

meanings.definition: showing admiration:

meanings.definition: to start to use a new product or service:
examples: Large firms lead small firms in terms of adopting e-commerce.

meanings.definition: If an animal or child is adoptable, they are available or suitable for adoption (= being permanently taken into someone's home as part of their family):
examples: At her clinic, she taught undisciplined dogs to behave better so they would be adoptable.
When he was 8, he appeared on a 1980s TV show featuring adoptable children.

meanings.definition: An adopted child has been legally taken by another family to be taken care of as their own child:
examples: They've got two adopted children and one of their own.

meanings.definition: An adopted country is one where someone chooses to live although they were not born there:
examples: Spain is my adopted country.

meanings.definition: (of a road, etc.) owned and maintained (= kept in good condition) by a local government:
examples: An adopted highway is maintained at public expense.

meanings.definition: someone who has been adopted as a child (= legally taken into another family and cared for as the family's own child):
examples: Her family included two adoptees, aged 3 and 2.
Support groups welcome birth parents, adoptees, and adoptive parents to share their experiences.

meanings.definition: a person or company that starts to use a new product or service:
examples: While large firms may be the most visible adopters of IT and e-commerce, smaller companies also face pressure to adopt these technologies.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         adopt
to legally take another person's child into your own family and take care of him or her as your own child:
examples: They've adopted a baby girl.
She had the child adopted (= she gave her baby to someone else to take care of).
They have no children of their own, but they're hoping to adopt.

meanings.definition: to take an animal that has been left in a place such as a rescue centre, and keep it as your pet:
examples: Only about 20 percent of all dogs and cats that come into the rescue centre will be adopted.
She lives in a 3-bedroomed home with five dogs she adopted from an animal shelter.

meanings.definition: to accept or start to use something new:
examples: I think it's time to adopt a different strategy in my dealings with him.
The new tax would force companies to adopt energy-saving measures.
He's adopted a remarkably light-hearted attitude towards the situation.

meanings.definition: to choose someone or something or take something as your own:
examples: Dr Kennedy has been adopted as the party's candidate for South Cambridge.

meanings.definition: to start behaving in a particular way, especially by choice:
examples: Roz has adopted one or two funny mannerisms since she's been away.

meanings.definition: to pay money in order to have your name connected with a particular thing, especially in order to help an organization raise money:
examples: For just $25, you can adopt a word for an entire year.

meanings.definition: to agree to be responsible for a road being maintained (= kept in good condition):
examples: The council said the road was never adopted and so it is not obliged to repair it.

meanings.definition: the act of legally taking a child to be taken care of as your own:
examples: She was homeless and had to put her child up for adoption (= ask for the child to be taken by someone else as their own).
The last ten years have seen a dramatic fall in the number of adoptions.

meanings.definition: accepting or starting to use something new:
examples: Several suggestions have been offered for adoption by the panel.

meanings.definition: choosing or taking something as your own:
examples: England was Conrad's country of adoption (= the country where he had chosen to live).
The adoption of a woman candidate was seen as controversial.

meanings.definition: the act of taking another person's child legally into your family to raise as your own child:
examples: The agency handles about a hundred adoptions a year.

meanings.definition: the act of accepting or beginning to use something:
examples: The adoption of a different insurance company caused a lot of confusion.

meanings.definition: the process of starting to use a new method, system, law, etc.:
examples: The adoption of tougher credit standards by mortgage lenders is making it hard for borrowers to qualify for new loans.

meanings.definition: the process of starting to use a new product or service:
examples: Mass adoption of broadband and social networking have made finding customers easier.
Misunderstanding of how these health plans work is preventing widespread adoption.
There has been a huge adoption rate for self-service check-in in the airline industry.
internet/e-commerce/technology adoption

meanings.definition: a drawing in the shape of a curved line that shows how quickly or slowly different types of people buy a new product, use a new technology, etc.
An adoptive parent is one who has adopted a child.
related, esp. as parents of someone, through adoption:
examples: Her adoptive parents were farmers.

meanings.definition: used to describe someone or something that makes you love or like them, usually because they are attractive and often small:
examples: She has the most adorable two-year-old girl.
These snowflake-shaped picture frames are just adorable.
I think it's adorable that your parents still hold hands.

meanings.definition: charming, attractive, and easily loved:
examples: He was an absolutely adorable child.

meanings.definition: in a way that makes you love or like something or someone, usually because they are attractive and often small:
examples: The puppy has the most adorably cute little face.
At the end of the film, they make up rather adorably and are last seen dancing together in silhouette.

meanings.definition: very strong love or worship for someone:
examples: her complete adoration of her brother
The painting depicts the Three Wise Men kneeling in adoration of the baby Jesus.

meanings.definition: a short form of adorable, used to describe people, animals, or things that are easy to like or love because they are so attractive:
examples: She shared an adorbs picture of her kids on her Instagram.
"Totes adorbs" is a slang abbreviation of "totally adorable" that's evolved among the 20 and under age group here in the States.

meanings.definition: to love someone very much, especially in a way that shows a lot of admiration or respect, or to like something very much:
examples: She has one son and she adores him.
I absolutely adore chocolate.
Don't you just adore lying in a hot bath?

meanings.definition: to worship:
examples: Let us adore God for all his works.

meanings.definition: to love and respect someone very much, or to like something very much:
examples: Both girls adored their father.
I adore those shoes!

meanings.definition: in a way that shows you love someone very much:
examples: She gazed at her baby adoringly.
He speaks adoringly of his wife.

meanings.definition: (of a person or a thing) socially awkward or not fashionable, but in a way that makes you love or like it or them :
examples: The main character is neurotic, nerdish and adorkable.
She wears those adorkable glasses.

meanings.definition: to add something decorative to a person or thing:
examples: The bride's hair was adorned with white flowers.

meanings.definition: to make something more attractive by putting something on it:
examples: The bride’s hair was adorned with fresh flowers.

abbreviation for American Depositary Receipt: a document used in US financial markets for buying shares in foreign companies. ADRs have prices in US dollars, pay dividends in US dollars, and are bought and sold in the same way as shares in US companies:
examples: The ADR program will broaden the existing market for the firm's stock, which in turn could drive up the price.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for alternative dispute resolution: a set of actions that are used by organizations to try to solve disagreements without using a court of law, for example arbitration and conciliation:
examples: In-house ADR programs can help employers avoid unnecessary lawsuits.

meanings.definition: used to refer to two glands situated above the kidneys (the adrenal glands)
the outer part of the adrenal gland
the outer part of the adrenal gland
one of a pair of glands that produce adrenalin, found just above the kidneys
either of two organs in the body that produce several chemical substances including adrenaline
the inner part of the adrenal gland that produces adrenaline
the inner part of the adrenal gland that producesadrenaline
an operation to remove the adrenal gland, often because of a tumour
a hormone produced by the body, for example when you are frightened, angry, or excited, that makes the heart beat faster and prepares the body to react to danger:
examples: These arguments always get my adrenalin going (= make me excited or angry).

meanings.definition: a hormone (= chemical substance) produced by the body when a person is frightened, angry, or excited, which makes the heart beat faster and prepares the body to react to danger
relating to the adrenal cortex (= the outer part of the adrenal gland)
a rare genetic disease that increases the amount of a particular type of fatty acid in the brain and adrenal glands, affecting their normal activity
If a boat is adrift, it is moving on the water but is not controlled by anyone because of a problem:
examples: He spent three days adrift on his yacht.

meanings.definition: If a person is adrift, they do not have a clear purpose in life or know what they want to do:
examples: Da Silva plays a bright, lonely student from New York, adrift in small-town Arizona.

meanings.definition: (of a boat) not fastened and moving with the sea and wind, or fig. not controlled and living without a clear purpose or direction:
examples: fig. Hopeful actors from small towns are often adrift in New York.

meanings.definition: very skilful and quick in the way you think or move:
examples: an adroit reaction/answer/movement of the hand
She became adroit at dealing with difficult questions.

meanings.definition: very skillful and quick in the way you think or move:
examples: She became adroit at dealing with difficult people.

meanings.definition: in a way that is very skilful, and quick in thinking or movement:
examples: She adroitly avoided the question.
He adroitly slipped the money into his pocket.

meanings.definition: the quality of being skilful and quick in thinking or movement:
examples: He has demonstrated his political adroitness many times.
She directs the conversation with the adroitness of a talk show host.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for American Depositary Share: a share in a foreign company bought and sold in US dollars in US financial markets. Each ADS is equal to one or more real shares in the company:
examples: Each ADS is equivalent to two shares in the company and is offered at a preliminary price range of $14 to $16.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for asymmetric digital subscriber line: a system for providing a very fast internet connection that allows you to use a phone at the same time

abbreviation for asymmetric digital subscriber line: a technology that allows large amounts of information to be sent to computers very quickly using ordinary phone lines. ADSL is one of the main technologies that provides broadband internet access:
examples: a high-speed ADSL service/network
an ADSL connection/line

meanings.definition: to cause a substance, usually a gas, to form a very thin layer on the surface of another substance
An adsorbent material causes a substance, usually a gas, to form a very thin layer on its surface. :
examples: Fuller’s earth is a highly adsorbent claylike substance.
Some specific gaseous pollutants may be removed by adsorbent beds.

meanings.definition: a material that causes a substance, usually a gas, to form a very thin layer on its surface:
examples: Several adsorbents are available, including silica gel and alumina.
Animal charcoal is used as an adsorbent to remove colouring matter from food liquids.

meanings.definition: the process in which a substance, usually a gas, forms a very thin layer on a surface:
examples: In simple terms, adsorption is the attraction of molecules onto the surface of a solid.
A carbon-impregnated pad is used for adsorption of liquid and gaseous impurities.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for accessory dwelling unit: a small home built on the same land as a larger home:
examples: An ADU might be a garage conversion or a basement conversion.
ADUs have their own kitchens and bathrooms, so they are fully self-contained.

meanings.definition:

to admire or praise someone very much, especially when this is more than is deserved:
examples: The boxer was convicted of rape, and yet is still adulated by many.

meanings.definition: very great admiration or praise for someone, especially when it is more than is deserved:
examples: As a born performer, she loves the excitement and she loves the adulation.

meanings.definition: too much admiration or praise for someone:
examples: He couldn’t deal with the adulation of his fans.

meanings.definition: showing great admiration or praise for someone, especially when it is more than is deserved:
examples: I found myself irritated by the adulatory tone of her biography.
The Mother Teresa article is adulatory.

meanings.definition: a person or animal that has grown to full size and strength:
examples: An adult under English law is someone over 18 years old.
Adults pay an admission charge but children get in free.

meanings.definition: grown to full size and strength:
examples: an adult male/elephant
She spent most of her adult life in Spain.

meanings.definition: typical of or suitable for adults:
examples: Let's try to be adult about this.

meanings.definition: Adult films, magazines, and books show naked people and sexual acts and are not for children.
grown to full size and strength:
examples: More than half of adult Americans are considered overweight.

meanings.definition: Adult also means suitable for grown people and not children:
examples: It’s a kids’ show, but they sneak in some adult humor.

meanings.definition: Adult movies, magazines, shows, and books include content that is intended for adults only.
classes for people who have finished their school education, usually taken in order to learn things they failed to learn in school
the period of someone's life when they are an adult:
examples: She spent most of her adult life in Spain.
We do not have to live our adult lives according to our parents' wishes.

meanings.definition:
the form of the disease diabetes that usually develops in later life and in which the body does not produce enough insulin, which is needed to control the level of sugar in the blood. 
        
         Type 2   is now the preferred term:
examples: Obesity is the primary cause of adult-onset diabetes.
The vast majority of diabetics have Type 2, or adult-onset diabetes, in which the body does not make enough insulin to control blood-sugar levels.

meanings.definition: a substance that has been added to a food, drug, or other substance that makes it weaker or lowers its quality, especially when that is harmful:
examples: Research indicated numerous cases of adulterants added to pet food ingredients.
The test results also will show any adulterants - substances blended with the narcotics.

meanings.definition: to make food or drink weaker or to lower its quality, by adding something else:
examples: There were complaints that the beer had been adulterated with water.

meanings.definition: to make something weaker or of worse quality by adding something else to it:
examples: Saffron is very expensive, and is often adulterated with other plants.

meanings.definition: Adulterated foods or drugs have been made weaker or worse in quality, especially by having something added to the them:
examples: There has been a government crackdown on adulterated animal feed.
The company was accused of distributing adulterated food.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         adulterate
to make food or drink weaker or to lower its quality, by adding something else:
examples: There were complaints that the beer had been adulterated with water.

meanings.definition: the act of making food or drugs worse in quality by adding something to them:
examples: The adulteration of poultry is considered a serious problem.
The presence of low levels of melamine in milk is not necessarily due to adulteration.

meanings.definition: a married person who has sex with someone who is not their wife or husband:
examples: Her husband was a compulsive adulterer.

meanings.definition: a married woman who has sex with someone who is not her husband or wife
involving sex between a married man or woman and someone who is not their wife or husband:
examples: He had an adulterous relationship with his wife's best friend.
He was born of an adulterous liaison between his mother and her brother-in-law.

meanings.definition: sex between a married man or woman and someone he or she is not married to:
examples: Many people in public life have committed adultery.

meanings.definition: sex between a married person and someone who is not that person’s wife or husband
the part of someone's life when they are an adult:
examples: People in England legally reach adulthood at 18.
Responsibility, I suppose, is what defines adulthood.

meanings.definition: the state of being an adult:
examples: When she reached adulthood, she moved away from home.

meanings.definition: the process or fact of treating or considering a child as if they are an adult, usually in a way that is wrong or harmful:
examples: She writes about how adultification leads to Black children being treated as criminals.
Some families rely on their eldest daughter to an extent that constitutes adultification.
Adultification bias is a form of racial prejudice where children in some groups are treated as being older than they actually are.

meanings.definition: to treat or consider a child as if they are an adult, usually in a way that is wrong or harmful:
examples: The perspective of the filmmaker adultifies the boys, making them responsible for adult choices.
As adultified children spend their adolescence taking on adult responsibilities and consequences, they often miss out on important experiences.

meanings.definition: actions and behaviour that are considered typical of adults, not children or young people:
examples: Why is adulting so hard?
Adulting includes things like keeping your home clean and paying bills.

meanings.definition: to give only the main facts and not the details about something, especially something that will happen in the future:
examples: The project's objectives were adumbrated in the report.

past simple and past participle of 
        
         adumbrate
to give only the main facts and not the details about something, especially something that will happen in the future:
examples: The project's objectives were adumbrated in the report.

to give only the main facts and not the details about something, especially something that will happen in the future:
examples: The project's objectives were adumbrated in the report.

meanings.definition: the act of giving the main facts and not the details about something, or something that gives these main facts:
examples: I admit that my adumbration of yesterday's meeting was scant.
The "people's budget" of 1909 was an early adumbration of the British welfare state.

meanings.definition: written abbreviation for adverb
to go or move something forward, or to develop or improve something:
examples: The fire advanced steadily through the forest.
We have advanced greatly in our knowledge of the universe.
He's just trying to advance (= improve) his own career.
The troops advanced on the city (= approached it, ready to attack).
Her study has considerably advanced (= helped) the cause of equal rights.

meanings.definition: to pay someone some money before the regular time:
examples: Could you advance me £500 until Tuesday?

meanings.definition: to suggest an idea or theory:
examples: the theory advanced in this article

meanings.definition: If something such as a share price advances, it increases in value:
examples: On the New York Stock Exchange, 1,228 issues advanced and 1,157 declined.

meanings.definition: the forward movement of something, or an improvement or development in something:
examples: Recent advances in medical science mean that this illness can now be cured.
Nothing could stop the advance of the floodwaters.

meanings.definition: money paid to someone before the regular time:
examples: She asked for a £300 advance on her salary.

meanings.definition: an attempt to start a sexual or romantic relationship with someone:
examples: She claimed that he made sexual advances towards her.
She rejected his unwelcome advances.

meanings.definition: something such as a share price that increases in value:
examples: Declining stocks easily defeated advances 413 to 302.

meanings.definition: happening, done, or ready before an event:
examples: We got no advance notice of the changes.
She gave me advance warning that she would visit the next day.
advance payment/booking

meanings.definition: to go or move something forward, or to develop or improve something:
examples: Research has advanced our understanding of the virus.
Tonight’s winner advances to the semifinals.

meanings.definition: happening before an event:
examples: We got no advance warning of the changes.

meanings.definition: money paid before something happens:
examples: Most authors get an advance on royalties they’ll earn later.

meanings.definition: an act of moving something forward or improving something:
examples: Technological advances have changed TV news.
The army’s advance was halted.
fig. She rejected his unwelcome advances (= attempts to make her interested in him).

meanings.definition: an improvement relating to a particular activity or area of knowledge:
examples: Doctors believe that the findings represent a major advance in treating heart disease.
The government's White Paper embodies the hopes of those who believe in the advance of the digital age.
What has been the impact of technological advances on the securities markets?
Advances in drilling and production technologies have significantly reduced the risk of a major oil spill.

meanings.definition: money that is paid to a person or organization before the usual time or before a piece of work is finished:
examples: Loans and advances usually represent the single largest asset of most banks.
Publishers generally pay an advance once the author finishes the manuscript.
The US singer will receive a $17.5m cash advance on signing the 10-year contract.

meanings.definition: an increase in the price or value of something such as a share or a currency:
examples: Declining stocks easily defeated advances 413 to 302.
Every one yen advance in the Japanese currency's value against the dollar could reduce current profits by as much as five billion yen.

meanings.definition: to develop and become successful, or to make something do this:
examples: Biotechnology continues to advance at a rapid pace.
She eventually advanced to vice-chairman of the bank.
Some employees decide to study for an MBA in order to advance their careers.

meanings.definition: to increase in value:
examples: On the New York Stock Exchange 1,128 issues advanced and 1,057 declined .
The general stock index advanced 1.94 points, or 0.04%, to 5291.45.
The dollar advanced against the Japanese yen.

meanings.definition: to increase in number, amount, or value:
examples: Overall, consumer prices are advancing at a modest rate.
Pre-tax profits advanced 10% to €252m.

meanings.definition: to suggest a new idea or plan to a group of people:
examples: Measures advanced by the General Assembly included reducing vehicle carbon-dioxide emissions.
Several proposals for reform were advanced by members of Congress.

meanings.definition: to give someone money before the usual time or before a piece of work is finished:
examples: Two weeks ago I hired him, and advanced him $10,000.
Evidence shows that lenders are becoming more discriminating in advancing loans to borrowers.

meanings.definition: to change the date or time of an event to an earlier one:
examples: No plans were made to advance the board meeting.

meanings.definition: done or made before something else happens:
examples: Critics argue that advance planning would have little impact on final policy decisions.
Having advance information can be a powerful tool to negotiating a rate on a loan.
Advance sales are down by about 3%.
Federal laws require companies to provide advance notice when laying off workers.
Russell has been offered an advance payment of $450,000 for her next novel.

meanings.definition: an arrangement to have tickets, a hotel room, etc. at a particular time in the future that you make some time before you go, or the process of making this arrangement:
examples: The show had already taken £4 million in advance bookings.
No advance booking is necessary on most departures.
Advance booking is strongly recommended.

meanings.definition: a copy of a book, report, speech, etc. that someone receives before it is published officially or before it is made available to members of the public:
examples: An advance copy of the report was provided to The New York Times.

meanings.definition: a written document in which a person says what type of medical treatment they would like or who can make decisions about their treatment if they become so ill that they are unable to make decisions or communicate their wishes themselves:
examples: Advance directives can give family members the confidence that they are following their loved one's wishes.
Caregivers should be aware of the need to have an advance healthcare directive.

meanings.definition: money that you pay to a person or company before receiving something such as a loan or investment:
examples: Some ATMs charge you a cash advance fee of $3 when you take money out of the machine.

meanings.definition: a dishonest business activity in which companies take money from customers as part of the payment for a loan, investment, etc. but never lend them the money, make the investment for them, etc.
a small military unit that moves forward during a military situation before the rest of the army:
examples: An advance guard went ahead to monitor the enemy positions and to check for mines and trip wires.
He was part of an advanced guard of highly trained troops to secure a landing site for the main task force.

meanings.definition: people or things that do something first, or go to a place before most other people:
examples: Backpackers are the advance guard, package tours the foot soldiers.
The insects reached the island a few days ago as the advanced guard of the infestations that have been blighting North Africa.

meanings.definition: information, especially official information, about something that is going to happen in the future:
examples: We got no advance notice of the changes.
Committee rules state that members must give the chairman advance notice of any official trips.

meanings.definition: an order for a product that is made before a product is available to buy:
examples: Advance orders for the book hit a record: 1.5 million in stores and online.

meanings.definition: the cheaper price that you pay for a plane, rail, etc. ticket when you buy it several days, weeks, or months before you make the journey:
examples: The airline is slashing 30 to 50% off its regular advance purchase fares.

meanings.definition: to help something develop or improve:
examples: The campaign seeks to advance the cause of equal rights for women everywhere.
He is untiring in his efforts to advance the cause in which he is interested.

meanings.definition: a warning about something that will or could happen in the future, especially something difficult or dangerous:
examples: They say they were not given any advance warning about yesterday's decision.
The planes could have avoided each other with only 30 seconds of advance warning.

meanings.definition: a mathematical method that is used to try and calculate whether an increase or reduction in share prices, etc. is likely to continue or change
modern and well developed:
examples: This is the most advanced type of engine available.
We have made great progress in advanced technologies such as biotechnology and AI.
This is a sturdy, reliable laptop for users who do not require a lot of advanced features.
Some advanced economies have started to look for alternatives to conventional coal and petroleum.
We understand these processes much better thanks to advanced brain-imaging techniques.

meanings.definition: at a higher, more difficult level:
examples: an advanced English course
When he got his PhD from Harvard in 1934, he became the first African American to earn this advanced degree in political science.

meanings.definition: having reached a late stage of development in a process:
examples: His mother was playing major concerts in the advanced stages of her pregnancy.
The corpse was in an advanced stage of decomposition.
The company said it is in advanced talks with several bidders, but would not give a timeline for when a deal would take place.

meanings.definition: An advanced illness or disease is one that has reached a late, and usually serious, stage of development:
examples: Vaccines are being tested as a treatment for advanced cancer.
Many people are at advanced stages of disease before they ever get tested.

meanings.definition: highly developed or difficult:
examples: Are you taking any advanced courses?

meanings.definition: using the most modern methods, technology, etc.:
examples: An advanced search engine allows you to add additional criteria to your query.
Peasant farmers in the region coexist with sectors of agriculture more advanced than any in Europe.
In addition to nuclear power, we are committed to developing advanced technologies for wind and solar energy.
advanced manufacturing/production methods
advanced countries/economies

meanings.definition: almost finished after a long period of work or discussion:
examples: Talks are understood to be at an advanced stage.
Two of the world's biggest postal groups are in advanced negotiations to set up a groundbreaking European strategic alliance.

meanings.definition: advanced courses of study or qualifications are intended for people who are already skilled or who have a good knowledge of a subject:
examples: Twenty thousand visas have been allocated for immigrants who earn advanced academic degrees.

meanings.definition: Someone who is of an advanced age or of advanced years is old:
examples: He was over sixty years old when he died, a relatively advanced age for his time.
He died from heart failure at the advanced age of ninety-four.
She kept fit well into her advanced years by swimming nearly every day.
He is a gentleman of advanced years, with a silver beard.

meanings.definition: the age of someone who is considered older than other people in the same group or doing the same thing:
examples: The advanced age of the mother raises the risk of birth defects in the baby.
She has launched a music career at the somewhat advanced age of 35.

meanings.definition: an economic and political system in which capitalism (= a system in which property and business are controlled by private owners rather than the state) has developed over a long period of time:
examples: He reported that social class inequalities are still a prominent feature of advanced capitalism.
The medical goods industries have become one of the most important areas of competition in advanced capitalism.

meanings.definition: a school or college class that is doing work at a higher, more difficult level than others:
examples: She enrolled her son in the advanced class.
We are running two intermediate classes and one advanced class.
We are now moving on to more advanced courses such as calculus.
Some students want access to advanced courses not offered in their schools.
She has enrolled in an advanced course in physics.

meanings.definition: a way of encrypting data (= protecting it by putting it into a form that can only be read by particular people) that is accepted and used by the US government:
examples: The new version's main selling point is stronger encryption using the Advanced Encryption Standard, which the federal government requires for handling sensitive information.

meanings.definition: in the US, courses offered to students at high school (= aged approximately 14 to 18) that are at the same level as college courses, and that give students college credits (= points for successfully completing an educational unit) if they pass a test at the end of the course:
examples: Increasing the number of minority students in Advanced Placement (AP) classes is a priority for us.
Advanced Placement is increasingly important to success after high school, and should not be denied to any student.
They are both 16 and juniors, and are preparing for Advanced Placement tests coming up soon.

meanings.definition: the development or improvement of something:
examples: All she was interested in was the advancement of her own career.

meanings.definition: an improvement relating to a particular activity or area of knowledge:
examples: The President's speech to the conference centered on the advancement of alternative fuel sources as a means of ensuring our future survival.
Nowadays, merger and acquisition transactions occur at a faster pace, due in part to advancements in communications.
technological/economic/medical advancement

meanings.definition: the process of improving your career, for example, by getting a more important position within an organization or by moving to another company for a better job:
examples: In order to keep good employees, you need to provide them with possibilities for growth and advancement.

meanings.definition: If you do something against time/the clock, you do it as fast as possible and try to finish it before a certain time:

meanings.definition: to make someone unhappy and angry:
