meanings.definition: shocked or surprised in an unpleasant way:
examples: Workers and union officials were aghast at the layoffs.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for adjusted gross income: in the US, the amount of someone's income that can be taxed. To calculate AGI, add the income from a person's salary, investments, etc. and then reduce this amount by deductions (= costs, for example, for medical care or loan interest).
able to move your body quickly and easily:
examples: Monkeys are very agile climbers.
You need to have agile fingers to do this kind of work.

meanings.definition: able to think quickly and clearly:
examples: For a man of 80, he has a remarkably agile mind.

meanings.definition: used for describing ways of planning and doing work in which it is understood that making changes as they are needed is an important part of the job
able to move about quickly and easily:
examples: Years of ballet and modern dance had made her strong and agile.
fig. He has an agile mind (= He can think quickly).

meanings.definition: able to deal with new situations or changes quickly and successfully:
examples: Most agile corporations have flexible management systems that can quickly accommodate global change and exploit opportunities.

meanings.definition: the ability to move your body quickly and easily:
examples: He has the agility of a mountain goat.
The acrobats display jawdropping feats of strength, agility, and control.

meanings.definition: the ability to think quickly and clearly:
examples: This job requires considerable mental agility.
We underestimate the agility of a child's mind.

meanings.definition: ways of planning and doing work in which it is understood that making changes as they are needed is an important part of the job:
examples: Business agility means a company is always in a position to take account of market changes.
Constant change is the new dynamic of the global economy, and makes agility even more necessary than ever.

meanings.definition: the ability to move about quickly and easily:
examples: A top-rated football player, he combines speed and agility.
fig. Her voice has the lightness and agility that Handel’s music demands.

meanings.definition: against:
examples: The whole world seemed agin him.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         ageing
being or appearing old:
examples: Oil companies are particularly concerned about their aging fleet of deep-water rigs.

meanings.definition: a way of organizing a company's accounts to show the length of time its customers have owed the company money:
examples: Financial analysts often use aging to assess a company’s risk from overdue debtors.

meanings.definition: becoming older, and not as modern or powerful as before:
examples: an aging market/customer/population
The agency is showing all the signs of an ageing company whose growth is too dependent on buying market size.

meanings.definition:
US spelling of 
        
         ageing out
a list of a company’s accounts receivable, which is arranged according to the length of time its customers have owed money:
examples: Most businesses prepare an accounts receivable aging schedule at the end of each month.

meanings.definition: the difference between the prices for buying and selling a particular currency
the cost of exchanging one currency for another:
examples: The agio charged for Euro transactions will be a minimum 0.50%.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         agiotage
the buying and selling of different currencies in order to make a profit from different exchange rates in different places:
examples: Agiotage represents one of four market roles in financial markets, distinct from hedging, long or short-term investing, and arbitrage.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         ageism
the act of treating people unfairly because of their age, especially if they are old:
examples: To protect yourself against agism during the recruiting process, some career experts suggest you remove the earliest work history from your resume.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         ageist
the use of popular music to spread political ideas, opinions, or information, or music used in this way
great worry or nervousness:
examples: The prospect of taking more risks gave them all agita.

meanings.definition: to make someone feel worried or angry:
examples: I didn't want to agitate her by telling her.

meanings.definition: to argue forcefully, especially in public, in order to achieve a particular type of change:
examples: The unions continue to agitate for higher pay.
As a young man, he had agitated against the Vietnam war.

meanings.definition: to shake a liquid:
examples: Pour the powder into the solution and agitate it until the powder has dissolved.

meanings.definition: to argue energetically, esp. in public, in order to achieve a particular type of change:
examples: Telephone companies began to agitate for permission to compete in long distance services.

meanings.definition: to make someone become nervous because of worry or fear that is difficult to control:
examples: Any mention of his son agitated him.

meanings.definition: worried or angry:
examples: She became very agitated when her son failed to return home.
There was a long delay, and people became increasingly agitated as they waited for the train.

meanings.definition: nervous because of worry or fear that is difficult to control:
examples: Gordon became visibly agitated when asked about the minimum wage issue.
Many times the private hospitals transfer their terribly aggressive, agitated patients to us because they cannot handle them.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         agitate
to make someone feel worried or angry:
examples: I didn't want to agitate her by telling her.

meanings.definition: to argue forcefully, especially in public, in order to achieve a particular type of change:
examples: The unions continue to agitate for higher pay.
As a young man, he had agitated against the Vietnam war.

meanings.definition: to shake a liquid:
examples: Pour the powder into the solution and agitate it until the powder has dissolved.

meanings.definition: worry and anxiety:
examples: He arrived home in a state of agitation.

meanings.definition: the situation in which people protest or argue, especially in public, in order to achieve a particular type of change:
examples: The anti-war agitation is beginning to worry the government.

meanings.definition: someone who tries to make people take part in protests and political activities, especially ones that cause trouble:
examples: It is thought that the strike was the work of undercover political agitators.

meanings.definition: (the spreading of) strongly political ideas or arguments expressed especially through plays, art, books, etc.
shining with light and colour:
examples: a city at night, aglow with lights
His face was all aglow with excitement.

meanings.definition: bright; shining:
examples: His eyes were aglow with pleasure.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         annual general meeting UK
abbreviation for annual general meeting: a meeting that happens once every year in which a company discusses its business activities, presents its accounts to shareholders, and elects officers:
examples: Mr Thomson was voted onto the board at the company's AGM two weeks ago.
The Agenda for the ensuing 7th AGM of the company's shareholders contains two special businesses.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for absorbent glass mat battery: a modern type of car battery (= a device that produces electricity to provide power) that provides a very good performance:
examples: AGM batteries are ideally suited for the sophisticated electrical systems and energy-consuming accessories of modern cars.
I put in an AGM battery, which cost more but it will last longer and charge more quickly.

meanings.definition: a condition in which scar tissue grows in the bone marrow so that not enough blood cells are produced for the body
a type of pasta made of small flat pieces that are folded, usually into a square shape, and filled with meat, vegetables, or cheese:
examples: My favourite from the pasta menu is the spinach and ricotta agnolotti.
The agnolotti were delicately seasoned with herbs.

meanings.definition: the state of being unable to recognize objects, caused by damage to the brain:
examples: visual agnosia

meanings.definition: someone who does not know, or believes that it is impossible to know, if a god exists:
examples: Although he was raised a Catholic, he was an agnostic for most of his adult life.
The group includes atheists and agnostics as well as religious believers.

meanings.definition: someone who does not know or does not have an opinion about whether something is true, good, correct, etc.:
examples: He claims to be an agnostic on the question of man-made global warming.
I am an agnostic when it comes to his art and its merits.

meanings.definition: having the belief that it is not possible to know whether god exists:
examples: Whether we are religious, atheist, or agnostic, there are some moral values we all share.
He is agnostic on the existence of God.

meanings.definition: not knowing or not having an opinion about whether something is true, good, correct, etc.:
examples: She remained agnostic on the question of whether to join the war.
We could never be agnostic about the virtues of political freedom.

meanings.definition: relating to hardware or software that can be used with many different types of platform (= system)
someone who believes that it is impossible to know whether or not God exists
the beliefs of someone who does not know, or believes that it is impossible to know, if a god exists:
examples: According to census figures, men significantly outnumber women in claiming agnosticism.
My agnosticism is easily explainable: I can't prove that God exists, and I can't prove that God does not exist.

meanings.definition: the fact that someone does not know or does not have an opinion about whether something is true, good, correct, etc.:
examples: They fear that the president's agnosticism about HIV will hamper his country's efforts to fight the epidemic.
Is there really enough remaining doubt about global warming to justify agnosticism?

meanings.definition: back in time from the present:
examples: He left the house over an hour ago.
The dinosaurs died out 65 million years ago.
Long ago/A long time ago, there lived a girl called Cinderella.

meanings.definition: back in the past; back in time from the present:
examples: That was a few years ago.
Your mother called about an hour ago.
Some time ago I read a book about that.
Are you still seeing Vivian? No, we stopped seeing each other a long time ago.

meanings.definition: excited and eager to know or see more:
examples: We waited agog for news.

meanings.definition: a muscle that moves a part of the body by contracting (= becoming shorter)
a substance that combines with a receptor and causes a change or reaction in the body:
examples: a dopamine agonist

meanings.definition:
a 
        
         protagonist
relating to fighting or aggression (= spoken or physical behaviour that is threatening or involves harm to someone or something):
examples: He published a study of agonistic behaviour in freshwater crayfish.

meanings.definition: relating to an agonist (= a muscle that is pulled in the opposite direction by another muscle):
examples: agonistic muscles

meanings.definition: to spend a lot of time trying to make a decision:
examples: He agonized for several days before agreeing to move to Oklahoma.

meanings.definition: to spend a lot of time trying to make a decision:
examples: She agonized for days over whether she should take the job.

meanings.definition: If you agonize over/about something, you spend time worrying and trying to make a decision about it:
examples: She agonized for days about whether she should take the job.

meanings.definition: showing or feeling extreme physical or mental pain:
examples: We heard an agonized cry.
She gave him an agonized look.

meanings.definition: causing extreme physical or mental pain:
examples: an agonizing death

meanings.definition: causing extreme worry:
examples: She went through an agonizing few weeks waiting for the test results.
We are faced with an agonizing choice/decision/dilemma.

meanings.definition: in a way that causes extreme physical or mental pain:
examples: My knee was agonizingly painful.
Agonizingly hard decisions must be made.

meanings.definition: extremely, in a way that is annoying or upsetting:
examples: Twice he's come agonizingly close to winning the race.
This is an agonizingly slow WiFi connection.

meanings.definition: extreme physical or mental pain or suffering:
examples: She lay there screaming in agony.
I was in an agony of suspense.
We've both suffered agonies of guilt over what happened.
It must be agony for them to say goodbye.

meanings.definition: extreme physical or mental pain or suffering, or a period of such suffering:
examples: They put her on painkillers, but they didn’t do enough, and she was in agony.

meanings.definition: a person, usually a woman, who gives advice to people with personal problems, especially in a regular magazine or newspaper article
the part of a magazine or newspaper where letters from readers about their personal problems are printed, together with advice about how to deal with them:
examples: She wrote in to an agony column.

meanings.definition: a man who gives advice to people with personal problems, especially in articles that appear regularly in a magazine or newspaper:
examples: His readers cherish him as an agony uncle who solves their problems.
He had become a kind of agony uncle to people in his community.

meanings.definition: in an ancient city, especially in ancient Greece, an open space where a market was held:
examples: Today it is possible to walk through the old agora (marketplace) and stroll along Roman roads.
The agora was where people gathered to shop, discuss politics, and meet friends.

meanings.definition: an open space, usually a public place, where people can meet:
examples: The agora area is where you can sit down, grab something to eat, and enjoy watching people.
The graduation ceremony usually takes place in the school auditorium or agora.

meanings.definition: a place on the internet that gives people the opportunity to freely exchange ideas:
examples: The news website opens up its agora, believing truth will rise from a clash of debaters from all regions and classes.
Please be respectful of others in this forum or agora, who have the right to free speech.

meanings.definition: fear of going outside and being in public places or of being in a situation from which it might be difficult to escape or in which help might not be available:
examples: Suffering from agoraphobia, she's afraid to even step outside her home.
It is estimated that approximately 500,000 adults in Great Britian suffer from agoraphobia to some extent.

meanings.definition: a person who suffers from agoraphobia
relating to or suffering from agoraphobia:
examples: She is agoraphobic and stays inside as much as she can.

meanings.definition: a serious disease that causes a reduction in the number of white blood cells (= blood cells that fight disease) in the blood, often caused by a reaction to certain drugs:
examples: The drug can cause agranulocytosis, a debilitating and often lethal drop in white blood cells that the body needs to fight infection.
A patient with agranulocytosis may not show many systemic signs of infection.

meanings.definition: a condition affecting the brain that makes it difficult for someone to write, especially after a brain injury:
examples: Aphasic agraphia is associated with spelling and grammatical errors.
Pure agraphia is a writing disorder in the absence of any other significant language disturbance.

meanings.definition: relating to the land, especially the use of land for farming:
examples: This is prime agrarian land.

meanings.definition: An agrarian place or country makes its money from farming rather than industry:
examples: This part of the country is mainly agrarian.

meanings.definition: relating to farming or farmers:
examples: The central government was urged to adopt a massive public investment programme in the agrarian sector to enhance grain production.
an agrarian economy/society/lifestyle
agrarian reform/laws/revolution

meanings.definition: to have the same opinion:
examples: Ann and I never seem to agree.
I agree with you on this issue.
My father and I don't agree about very much.
My father and I don't agree on very much.
I agree that he should be invited.
Experts seem unable to agree whether the drug is safe or not.
"You're absolutely right," agreed Jake.

meanings.definition: to decide something together:
examples: They agreed not to tell anyone about what had happened.
We couldn't agree on what to buy.
We finally agreed a deal.

meanings.definition: to accept a suggestion or idea:
examples: I suggested that we should meet, and they agreed (= said yes).
The bank has agreed (= is willing) to lend me £5,000.

meanings.definition: If two or more statements, ideas, sets of numbers, etc. agree, they are the same or very similar:
examples: We have five accounts of what happened and none of them agree.

meanings.definition: When two words agree, or one word agrees with another word, they have the same grammatical form. For example, the words may both be singular or plural, masculine or feminine, etc.
to have the same opinion, or to accept a suggestion or idea:
examples: I agree with you.
We all agree on that point.
In settling the dispute, he agreed to pay $60,000 in damages.
Most economists agree that it would be unwise to cut taxes right now.
Both sides agreed to the terms of the peace treaty.
I agree with letting children learn at their own pace.

meanings.definition: If two sets of information agree, they are generally the same:
examples: Since their stories did not agree at all, he knew one of them was lying.

meanings.definition: to accept someone else’s plan, suggestion, etc.:
examples: Federal regulators and US lenders agreed to freeze interest rates on subprime mortgages for five years.
Any change to branch rules must be agreed by two thirds of members at the branch meeting.
The union's national executive committee will meet on Thursday to agree the new strategy.

meanings.definition: to have the same opinion, or to approve of someone else’s ideas and opinions:
examples: The credit card company agreed that we'd been overcharged and will credit the amount in our next bill.
Although we like his plan in general, we don't agree with him on every issue.

meanings.definition: to accept that you have different opinions from another person about a particular thing, and stop trying to persuade each other that you are right:
examples: Her parents are Republicans, and they have agreed to differ with their daughter.
There are areas where we will simply have to agree to disagree.

meanings.definition: to accept something:
examples: Both sides in the conflict have agreed to the terms of the peace treaty.

meanings.definition: to accept someone else’s plan, suggestion, etc.:
examples: Often promoters will try to get people to agree to a deal by saying the offer is valid only for a short period of time.

meanings.definition: to think that something is morally acceptable:
examples: I don't agree with hunting.

meanings.definition: If a situation or new conditions agree with you, they make you feel healthy and happy:
examples: You look well - the mountain air must agree with you.

meanings.definition: to cause someone to feel healthy and happy:
examples: You both look great – marriage must agree with you.
The fish dinner on our flight did not agree with me (= made me feel ill).

meanings.definition: pleasant or pleasing:
examples: We spent a most agreeable evening by the river.

meanings.definition: able to be accepted by everyone:
examples: The talks are aimed at finding a mutually agreeable solution.
We need to find a compromise that is agreeable to both sides of the party.

meanings.definition: willing to do or accept something:
examples: If Bridget is agreeable to the proposal, we'll start the project in June.

meanings.definition: pleasant; pleasing:
examples: She has an agreeable personality.

meanings.definition: acceptable or satisfactory:
examples: We prefer to reach a solution agreeable to all interested parties.

meanings.definition: Someone who is agreeable to doing something is willing to do it:
examples: We can close the deal tomorrow if your client is agreeable.

meanings.definition: the quality of being friendly and pleasant:
examples: She was noted for her pleasant manner and agreeableness.
Five factors are said to underlie personality: emotional stability, extraversion, openness to experience, agreeableness, and conscientiousness.

meanings.definition: the quality of being enjoyable and pleasant to do:
examples: The agreeableness of yesterday's engagement had surprised her.
Both wages and profits vary with differences in the agreeableness of the work.

meanings.definition: pleasantly, or with enjoyment or pleasure:
examples: We were agreeably surprised by the price.
The day was agreeably warm after the cool night.

meanings.definition: with enjoyment or pleasure:
examples: They were agreeably surprised to see that he’d come after all.

meanings.definition: accepted:
examples: We have to stick to the agreed price.
"So we'll meet at 5.30, shall we?" "Agreed (= yes)."

meanings.definition: accepted or approved:
examples: The agreed deal also marks a new record in foreign take-overs of US banks.
an agreed price/time/date

meanings.definition: an offer to buy enough shares in a company to gain control of it, which the company's directors suggest that shareholders accept:
examples: An agreed bid could ultimately satisfy shareholders on both sides.

meanings.definition: an amount that an insurance company agrees to insure a property for at the start of an insurance period, and that it will pay if the property is lost or destroyed:
examples: Marine insurance policies can either specify an agreed value or specify that a value be determined when a claim is made.
agreed value coverage/option/provision

meanings.definition: insurance for an amount agreed to by an insurance company at the start of an insurance period, rather than at the time the property is lost or destroyed:
examples: Agreed value insurance guarantees you will get all of your money back in the event of total loss to your classic car.

meanings.definition:
present participle of 
        
         agree
to have the same opinion:
examples: Ann and I never seem to agree.
I agree with you on this issue.
My father and I don't agree about very much.
My father and I don't agree on very much.
I agree that he should be invited.
Experts seem unable to agree whether the drug is safe or not.
"You're absolutely right," agreed Jake.

meanings.definition: to decide something together:
examples: They agreed not to tell anyone about what had happened.
We couldn't agree on what to buy.
We finally agreed a deal.

meanings.definition: to accept a suggestion or idea:
examples: I suggested that we should meet, and they agreed (= said yes).
The bank has agreed (= is willing) to lend me £5,000.

meanings.definition: If two or more statements, ideas, sets of numbers, etc. agree, they are the same or very similar:
examples: We have five accounts of what happened and none of them agree.

meanings.definition: When two words agree, or one word agrees with another word, they have the same grammatical form. For example, the words may both be singular or plural, masculine or feminine, etc.
the situation in which people have the same opinion, or in which they approve of or accept something:
examples: The whole family was in agreement with her about/on what they should do.
If the three parties cannot reach agreement now, there will be a civil war.
I don't think you'll ever get Tony's agreement to these proposals.
There's widespread agreement that the law should be changed.

meanings.definition: a decision or arrangement, often formal and written, between two or more groups or people:
examples: The dispute was settled by an agreement that satisfied both sides.
The government has entered into/signed an international arms control agreement.
They have broken (the terms of) the agreement on human rights.
Finally the two sides have reached an agreement.

meanings.definition: the situation in which two words have the same grammatical form. For example, the words are both singular or plural, masculine or feminine, etc.
the condition of having the same opinion, or a decision or arrangement between two or more people or groups to do something or to obey the same rules:
examples: a new trade agreement
Both sides were in agreement on the basic terms, but many details still had to be worked out.
Leaders of both countries signed an agreement to exchange diplomats.
Let us help you to reach agreement.

meanings.definition: a decision or arrangement that has been made and accepted by two or more people, groups, organizations, etc.:
examples: Based on the rental agreement between the landlord and the tenant, either party must give 30 days notice to terminate the agreement.
The group has licensing agreements with 170 retail customers in the US.
Negotiations will continue for an ambitious agreement on trade and other matters.
Despite recent discussions between the two companies, they failed to reach an agreement on the terms of a possible merger.
Developers have signed an agreement with the commission and the EPA to use the land for commercial and residential property.
a formal/legal/binding agreement
a verbal/written/unwritten agreement

meanings.definition: the act of approving or accepting something, or the fact of having the same opinion about something:
examples: Most of the county's lawmakers are in agreement with administration officials on the proposal.
There is widespread agreement that changes need to be made, but there is disagreement about how it should be conducted.
All area superintendents are in agreement that both constitutional reform and tax reform are necessary now.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         purchase agreement
the various businesses that are connected with producing, preparing, and selling farm products
the different types of businesses that are involved in farming, such as growing crops, supplying seeds, manufacturing farm equipment, and marketing farm products:
examples: Over half the nation’s land area is devoted to farming and approximately 16% of total employment is in agribusiness.

meanings.definition: farming using modern equipment and methods, considered an important industry:
examples: The term “agribusiness” is sometimes used negatively by critics of large-scale, industrialized food production.

meanings.definition: used for farming or relating to farming:
examples: The world's supply of agricultural land is shrinking fast.
She's studying agricultural science.
The country's economy is mainly agricultural (= based on farming).

meanings.definition: relating to or used in farming:
examples: Over the past ten years, their agricultural exports to the United States grew by 133%.
agricultural machinery/equipment/land
the agricultural industry/sector/economy

meanings.definition: a type of bank that lends money to farmers for longer periods of time and charges them less interest than other types of banks:
examples: Stakeholders in agriculture have pressed the government to establish the newly proposed agricultural bank.

meanings.definition: an organization in which many small farms work together as a business, especially to help each other produce and sell their crops:
examples: Farmers with common interests often organize through agricultural cooperatives to strengthen their market power.

meanings.definition: the use of scientific research and new information to improve farming methods by educating farmers:
examples: The college is responsible for agricultural extension and training in the area.
He is an agricultural extension agent who works with dairy farmers in four Piedmont counties.
The role of the agricultural extension service is to introduce new technologies, and advise farmers on various aspects of crop production.

meanings.definition: a public event that shows new or high quality examples of farming skills, farm equipment, animals, crops, etc.:
examples: This year’s agricultural show will feature exhibitions from the nation’s top horse and cattle breeders.

meanings.definition: farming:
examples: Agriculture is still largely based on traditional methods in some countries.
The area depends on agriculture for most of its income.
70 percent of the country's population practises subsistence agriculture.

meanings.definition: the practice or work of farming:
examples: Agriculture and tourism are both important to the region’s economy.

meanings.definition: the business, science, or activity of farming:
examples: Recent floods have devastated the state’s agriculture, with sharp declines in its production of corn, soy, and wheat crops.
Over the past ten years the area’s labour force has shifted from agriculture to manufacturing.

meanings.definition: a plant with small yellow flowers on a single stem, used in traditional medicine:
examples: Agrimony is quite a small plant, and can easily be overlooked in long grass.
Agrimony was gargled to relax sore throats.

meanings.definition: the business of providing holidays for people on farms or in the countryside
farming considered as a business:
examples: Cuba's sugar agro-industry is currently undergoing a radical transformation.

meanings.definition: the part of the economy relating to farming, for example, farmers, manufacturers of farm equipment, and importers and exporters of farm products:
examples: By developing the agro-industry we can promote the welfare of the agricultural sectors as well as attain overall economic growth.

meanings.definition: a chemical that is used in farming to help grow crops or kill insects
a chemical that is used in farming to increase crop production or kill insects:
examples: They produce a wide range of agrochemicals including pesticides, fungicides, herbicides, and seed treatments.

meanings.definition: the science or the activity of following the principles of ecology (= the study of how different parts of the environment relate to one another) in farming systems:
examples: If they understood agroecology they would acknowledge that soil must be understood as a complex ecosystem.

meanings.definition: agriculture (= farming) that involves growing and caring for trees:
examples: These Javanese communities have practised agroforestry in the forests since the tenth century.

meanings.definition: a scientist who works in agronomy (= the science of farming):
examples: Agronomists were working on new ways to create healthier food while managing the environmental impact of agriculture.

meanings.definition: the science of farming, including the study of soil, plants, and animals, and ways to improve the production of food on farms:
examples: Agronomy encompasses work in many areas including plant genetics, crop rotation, irrigation, and food production.

meanings.definition: If a boat or ship is aground, it is unable to move because it is touching ground or in a place where there is very little water:
examples: The ship is currently aground off the Brittany coast.

meanings.definition: touching the ground below the water:
examples: The tanker ran aground and leaked 11 million gallons of crude oil.

meanings.definition: a fever in which your body shakes, especially one caused by malaria
used to express understanding, pleasure, pain, surprise, or the fact that you have noticed something:
examples: Ah, I see.
Why has the train stopped? Ah, now we're off again.
Ah, Jessica, how wonderful to see you!
Ah, what a lovely baby!

meanings.definition: used to show a sudden feeling, such as one of surprise, pleasure, or understanding:
examples: Ah, so that’s what the problem was!

meanings.definition: used when you suddenly understand or find something:
examples: Aha, now I see what you mean!
Aha, that's where I put my keys!

meanings.definition: abbreviation for alpha-hydroxy acid: a type of organic acid that is used in some products intended to remove dead skin cells and to make the skin look healthy, attractive, and young:
examples: AHAs (acids derived from milk and fruit sugars) are added to prescription skin creams and cosmetics.
She has sensitive skin and avoids anti-ageing creams containing AHA.

meanings.definition: used to express pleasure at suddenly understanding or learning the truth about something:
examples: Aha! We've found the solution!

meanings.definition: in front:
examples: The road ahead is very busy.
Turn left at the traffic lights, and you'll see the hospital straight ahead.

meanings.definition: having more points, votes, etc. than someone else in a competition, election, etc.:
examples: Barcelona was ahead after ten minutes.

meanings.definition: making more progress than someone else:
examples: All the children in the class are doing well, but Sophie is way (= far) ahead.

meanings.definition: In baseball, if the pitcher (= the player who throws the ball) is ahead in the count or ahead of the batter, they have thrown more strikes (= balls inside the hitting area) than balls outside the hitting area:
examples: He likes to throw his curveball when he is ahead in the count.
He threw a lot of strikes and consistently got ahead of the opposing hitters.

meanings.definition: in or into the future:
examples: He couldn't bear to think of the lonely year ahead.

meanings.definition: earlier than or before someone or something:
examples: It was already 10 AM in Moscow when the news broke in London that morning, because Moscow is three hours ahead.

meanings.definition: directly in front:
examples: She only had a few things in her shopping cart, so I told her she could go ahead of me in the checkout line.

meanings.definition: Ahead also means further along in development or achievement:
examples: Sophie is way ahead of the rest of her class.

meanings.definition: in or into the future:
examples: We have a lot of hard work ahead of us.
You have to plan ahead when you’re thinking of going to graduate school.

meanings.definition: at a better, higher, or greater level than before:
examples: First-half figures showed that pre-tax profits were ahead by 8% to £94.8m.
Full-year profits jumped 25% to £106m pre-tax, which was ahead of expectations.

meanings.definition: more developed, advanced, or able to succeed:
examples: To get ahead in the industry you need the right tools and the right connections.
After showing signs of slowing sales growth, the group cut its prices to stay ahead of its rivals.

meanings.definition: in front of someone or something:
examples: Rick walked on ahead of us.
He could see that the road ahead of him was clear.
Just ahead of you, you'll see a bus stop.
You go on ahead of (= before) me, and I'll meet you there.

meanings.definition: having more points, votes, etc. than someone else in a competition, election, etc.:
examples: Apparently, the latest opinion polls put the Democrats 15 percent ahead of the Republicans.

meanings.definition: making more progress than someone else:
examples: Sophie is way (= far) ahead of the other children in her class.

meanings.definition: in or into the future:
examples: She has a difficult time ahead of her.

meanings.definition: earlier than or before someone or something:
examples: This was one Olympic site that had been completed ahead of schedule (= before the time that was arranged).
The agenda is circulated to householders one month ahead of the meeting.
For most of the year London is five hours ahead of New York (= when it is 10 o'clock in London, it is 5 o'clock in New York).

meanings.definition: early:
examples: We expect the building work to be completed ahead of schedule.
The project came in several months ahead of schedule.
We're actually on course and possibly even slightly ahead of schedule.
The freelancers are working ahead of schedule, so we will need to find more work for the duration of their contract.
I'm delighted to report that we're ahead of schedule.

meanings.definition: earlier than a particular moment:
examples: Let's meet for lunch. I'll call you ahead of time to decide exactly when and where.
Officials were notified ahead of time.
Make the dish a few hours ahead of time to let the flavours develop.
The president was briefed ahead of time.
She always planned our meals ahead of time.
I got to the venue ahead of time so I could scout out a good seat.

meanings.definition: having new ideas, opinions, or ways of living long before most other people do:
examples: The documentary shows a modern woman years ahead of her time.
The King was talking about environmental destruction several decades ago - he was really ahead of his time.
She was ahead of her time in her child-centred approach to teaching.
Everyone's doing it now, but when they introduced the idea thirty years ago, they were ahead of their time.
A feminist and an environmentalist, she was way before her time.

meanings.definition: used to represent the little cough that someone makes to express slight embarrassment, enjoyment, doubt, or disapproval, or to attract attention
a large city in the western part of India:
examples: After the 2010 heat wave became apparent, Ahmedabad began formulating a plan for coping with extreme temperatures.
She lived in the state capital, Ahmedabad, for five months and found it an inspiring experience.

meanings.definition: unable to stop doing, eating, or drinking something:
examples: a workaholic
an alcoholic
a chocoholic

meanings.definition: a shout used, especially by people in boats, to attract attention:
examples: Ahoy there!

meanings.definition: used, especially on a boat, when you see something, usually something that is in the distance:
examples: Land ahoy!
Ship ahoy!

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for 
        
         artificial intelligence  : the use or study of computer systems or machines that have some of the qualities that the human brain has, such as the ability to interpret and produce language in a way that seems human, recognize or create images, solve problems, and learn from data supplied to them:
examples: The highly realistic "photograph" was actually fake, generated by AI.
AI has helped to create a new antibiotic to combat a deadly superbug.
They called for a pause in the creation of giant AI systems, so that the risks can be properly understood.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for 
        
         artificial intelligence  : a particular computer system or machine that has some of the qualities that the human brain has, such as the ability to interpret and produce language in a way that seems human, recognize or create images, solve problems, and learn from data supplied to it:
examples: Would it be possible for an AI to build artificial life forms?
Some people believe that we will soon be able to create sentient AIs.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for artificial insemination: the process of putting sperm into a female using methods that do not involve sexual activity between a male and female:
examples: The surrogate was impregnated through AI (artificial insemination), thus donating her genetic material as well as carrying the pregnancy herself.

meanings.definition: the study of how to make computers that have some of the qualities of the human mind, for example the ability to understand language, recognize pictures, solve problems, and learn:
examples: Telecommunication and medical industries are harnessing AI developments to improve speech recognition technologies.

meanings.definition: computer technology that allows something to be done in a way that is similar to the way a human would do it:
examples: The techniques of AI are becoming more important, both in industry (eg in robotics ) and in pure research.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants
a piece of equipment that helps you to do something:
examples: teaching aids, such as books and videos
A thesaurus is a useful aid to writing.

meanings.definition: help in the form of food, money, medical supplies, or weapons that is given by a richer country to a poorer country:
examples: The Vatican has agreed to donate £80,000 in humanitarian aid to countries affected by the war.
The company agreed to donate £500 in emergency aid to the clean-up efforts.
About a fifth of the country's income is in the form of foreign aid.

meanings.definition: to help:
examples: Huge projects designed to aid poorer countries can sometimes do more harm than good.
His excuse for drinking brandy is that it's said to aid digestion.

meanings.definition: help or support, or something that provides it:
examples: He gets around with the aid of a cane.
She went to the aid of a man trapped in his car.
A good dictionary can be a useful aid to understanding a new language.

meanings.definition: Aid is often used to refer to help given in the form of food, money, medical supplies, etc., to a country or group of people that is in need or because of an emergency:
examples: foreign aid
Aid for the flood victims was on the way.

meanings.definition: money, food, medicine, or other supplies that are sent to people or countries who need them because of a difficult situation:
examples: The government has already appealed for 800,000 tonnes of food aid to feed its starving population.
economic/emergency/humanitarian aid
Victims of the flood can receive aid at one of the 19 emergency aid stations set up by the state.
foreign/international/overseas aid

meanings.definition: help or support:
examples: Lawmakers say the plan will create 1 million jobs and provide comfort and aid to the poor.
The Bureau will come to the aid of any homeowners pursuing an insurance claim.
Under the plan, state aid to local businesses would drop by $6.6 million.

meanings.definition: to help or support someone or something:
examples: Better training policies and new technologies are aiding disabled people in the workplace.
An additional team of contractors was hired to aid in the plant's construction.

meanings.definition: an organization that provides money, food, medicine, or other supplies in order to help people or countries that are suffering:
examples: Aid agencies launched financial appeals and prepared emergency teams to fly in to assess the scale of the disaster.

meanings.definition: to help someone to do something illegal or wrong:
examples: Three auditors were accused of aiding and abetting the men charged with fraud.
They were taken to jail and charged with aiding and abetting illegal immigration.
She pleaded guilty, admitting she had aided and abetted the bombing plot.
Farmers (aided and abetted by scientists) then started breeding tomatoes for transportability rather than taste.
The supporting actor stole the show, aided and abetted by his three child co-stars.

meanings.definition: a place where medical help is provided for soldiers, etc. who are injured while fighting:
examples: He probably would have bled to death if we hadn't got him to the aid station.

meanings.definition: a place where help, including food and drink, is provided for people who need it:
examples: After the hurricane, state and federal officials set up 16 to 20 aid stations in Southeast Texas.
I stopped at an aid station and saw a bus loading up runners who couldn't reach the finish on their own.

meanings.definition: someone who is working in a country where there is a war, no food, etc., in order to help people

abbreviation for attention, interest, desire, action: a process used to sell a product or service, which involves getting a customer's attention, making them interested in it, making them want it, and then making them buy it:
examples: The final step in the AIDA marketing model is getting the user to take action.

meanings.definition: a person whose job is to help someone important, such as a member of a government or a military officer of high rank:
examples: a senior government aide
an aide to the prime minister

meanings.definition: a person whose job is to help someone important, such as a member of a government or a military officer of high rank:
examples: The senator asked an aide to distribute copies of his speech.

meanings.definition: a military or naval officer who helps an officer of higher rank:
examples: He became Napoleon's aide-de-camp in 1804.

meanings.definition: something, usually written, that helps you to remember something

past simple and past participle of 
        
         aid
to help:
examples: Huge projects designed to aid poorer countries can sometimes do more harm than good.
His excuse for drinking brandy is that it's said to aid digestion.

meanings.definition: a person who helps someone to do a particular thing, especially something bad:
examples: They were his chief aiders and assistants in carrying out his plans.
They became not only passive observers but willing aiders.

meanings.definition:
plural of 
        
         aide-de-camp

present participle of 
        
         aid
to help:
examples: Huge projects designed to aid poorer countries can sometimes do more harm than good.
His excuse for drinking brandy is that it's said to aid digestion.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome: a serious disease caused by a virus that destroys the body's natural protection from infection:
examples: Don had full-blown AIDS for over a year before he died.
people living with AIDS

meanings.definition: abbreviation for acquired immune deficiency syndrome (= serious disease caused by a virus that destroys the body’s natural protection from infection and can result in death)
the virus that causes AIDS (= a serious disease that destroys the body's ability to fight infections). Human immunodeficiency virus is now the preferred term:
examples: Patients tested for the AIDS virus previously had to wait a week for their results.
Medications can reduce the level of the AIDS virus in the blood to zero, but HIV doesn't disappear and comes back if patients stop taking their pills.

meanings.definition: a sport, created in Japan as a type of self-defence, in which you hold and throw your opponent and use his or her own movements:
examples: Aikido's core philosophy is overcoming opponents without doing them physical harm.
I took my kids to aikido practice.

meanings.definition: to cause difficulty and problems for someone or something:
examples: The government seems to have no understanding of what ails the country.

meanings.definition: to be ill, or to cause to be ill:
examples: She had been ailing for years before she died.

meanings.definition: to feel or cause someone to feel ill, unhealthy, or weak:
examples: I don’t know what’s ailing her.

meanings.definition: a deciduous tree (= one that loses its leaves in autumn and grows new ones in the spring) with large leaves, originally from Asia but widely found in North America:
examples: Ailanthus is probably the most invasive tree in the national park and efforts have been made to control its spread.
An ailanthus sprouts on the harbour's shore.
The deciduous trees - elms, honey locusts, cottonwoods and ailanthus - will do well.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         ail
to cause difficulty and problems for someone or something:
examples: The government seems to have no understanding of what ails the country.

meanings.definition: to be ill, or to cause to be ill:
examples: She had been ailing for years before she died.

meanings.definition: a part along the back edge of an aircraft's wing that can be moved to help the aircraft turn or to keep it level
experiencing difficulty and problems:
examples: the country's ailing economy
Ted asked me if I could help him fix his ailing car.

meanings.definition: weak and suffering from illness:
examples: He's visiting his ailing father.

meanings.definition: unhealthy or weak, and not getting any better:
examples: The plan was supposed to give a boost to our ailing economy.

meanings.definition: experiencing financial problems:
examples: The ailing company shut down two of its smaller plants in an attempt to trim costs.

meanings.definition: an illness:
examples: Treat minor ailments yourself.

meanings.definition: an illness or health problem:
examples: a respiratory/stomach ailment

meanings.definition: a result that your plans or actions are intended to achieve:
examples: My main aim in life is to be a good husband and father.
Our short-term aim is to deal with our current financial difficulties, but our long-term aim is to improve the company's profitability.
The leaflet has been produced with the aim of increasing public awareness of the disease.

meanings.definition: the act of pointing a weapon towards something:
examples: He fired six shots at the target, but his aim was terrible, and he missed all of them.
She raised her gun, took aim and fired.

meanings.definition: to intend:
examples: I aim to be a millionaire by the time I'm 35.
We are aiming for (= planning to achieve) a 50 percent share of the German market.

meanings.definition: to point or direct a weapon towards someone or something that you want to hit:
examples: Aim (the arrow) a little above the target.
Aim at the yellow circle.
There are hundreds of nuclear missiles aimed at the main cities.
She aimed (= directed) a kick at my shins.
Let's aim for (= go in the direction of) Coventry first, and then we'll have a look at the map.

meanings.definition: to point or direct a weapon or other object toward someone or something:
examples: I turned and saw a big man aiming a camera at me.

meanings.definition: To aim something is also to direct it toward someone whom you want to influence or toward achieving something:
examples: These ads are aimed at young people.

meanings.definition: to plan for a specific purpose; intend:
examples: The measures aimed at preserving family life.
This book aims at attracting the serious reader.

meanings.definition: a result that your plans or actions are intended to achieve:
examples: The commission’s aim was to convince workers of their extreme importance in ship production.

meanings.definition: the act of pointing a weapon toward something:
examples: She raised her bow, took aim, and hit the bull’s-eye.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Alternative Investment Market: a stock market for small companies that is part of the London Stock Exchange:
examples: Originally an AIM share, SFI now has a full listing on the main stock market.

meanings.definition: something that you plan or hope to achieve:
examples: Our aim is customer satisfaction.
Environmentalists designed the project with the aim of increasing awareness of industrial pollution.

meanings.definition: to plan or hope to achieve something:
examples: A spokesman for the company says they are aiming to increase sales by 25% next year.
The former Senator now aims for a political appointment in Washington.

meanings.definition: to plan, hope, or intend to achieve something:
examples: The talks are aiming at a compromise.
The government's campaign is aimed at influencing public opinion.

meanings.definition: If information is aimed at a particular group of people, it is made known in a way that influences them or makes them interested in something:
examples: These advertisements are specifically aimed at young people.

meanings.definition: to produce something for a particular purpose or a particular group of people:
examples: The new budget aims at providing extra support for the unemployed.
The new photo editing software is being aimed at mobile application developers.

meanings.definition: used to describe a company whose shares are bought and sold on the AIM:
examples: Many AIM-listed internet start-ups are increasing in value.

meanings.definition:

to intend:

meanings.definition: without any clear intentions, purpose, or direction:
examples: She said that her life seemed aimless after her children left home.

meanings.definition: without having any clear purpose or specific reason:
examples: aimless violence

meanings.definition: in a way that is aimless (= without clear intentions, purpose, or direction):
examples: While she waited, she walked aimlessly around the car park.
She wandered aimlessly through the cold morning streets, not sure which way she was going.

meanings.definition: the condition of being without clear intentions, purpose, or direction:
examples: She worried about her son's lack of ambition and apparent aimlessness.
The film contrasts the quiet of nature with the busy aimlessness of modern industrial life.

meanings.definition: short form of am not, is not, are not, has not, or have not:
examples: He ain't going.
"Can I have a cigarette?" "I ain't got none left."

meanings.definition: contraction of am not, is not, are not, has not, or have not:
examples: "Is Terry here?" "No, he ain’t coming in today."

meanings.definition: short form of are you not:
examples: You're having a laugh, aintcha?

meanings.definition: a cold, thick sauce made from garlic, eggs, and olive oil
the mixture of gases that surrounds the earth and that we breathe:
examples: I went outside to get some fresh air.
You should put some air in your tyres - they look flat to me.

meanings.definition: the distance above the ground achieved by jumping or by hitting or throwing a ball:
examples: A 10-metre half pipe ramp allows the skateboarders to get massive air.
She gave her lob plenty of air.

meanings.definition: travel in an aircraft:
examples: I don't travel much by air.
an air crash/disaster
air travel

meanings.definition: manner or appearance:
examples: She has an air of confidence about her.

meanings.definition: a simple tune:
examples: Bach's Air on a G String

meanings.definition: to make opinions or complaints known to other people:
examples: Putting a complaint in the suggestions box is one way of airing your grievances.
He'll air his views on the war, whether people want to listen or not.

meanings.definition: to become dry and/or fresh, or to cause to become dry and/or fresh:
examples: My mother always airs the sheets before she makes the beds.
Leave the windows open to let the room air a bit.

meanings.definition: to broadcast something or be broadcast on radio or television:
examples: The game will be aired live on CBS at 7.00 tonight.
The interview with the president will air tomorrow morning.

meanings.definition: to intentionally ignore or not answer someone:
examples: Why is he airing me?
You asked a question and you got aired.

meanings.definition: the mixture of gases that surrounds the earth and that we breathe:
examples: Let’s go outside for some fresh air.

meanings.definition: Air pressure is the force that air produces when it presses against any surface.
the space above, esp. high above, the ground:
examples: Keith kicked the football high in the air.

meanings.definition: flight above the ground, esp. in an aircraft:
examples: air travel
You can get there by train, but it’s faster by air.

meanings.definition: a manner or appearance:
examples: She had an air of confidence.

meanings.definition: to broadcast something on radio or television:
examples: The game will be aired at 9 p.m. tomorrow.

meanings.definition: to make your opinions or complaints known to other people:
examples: The meeting gave us a chance to air our complaints.

meanings.definition: to let air from outside come in a room or other inside space to make it smell cleaner, or to put something outside in the air to make it smell cleaner:
examples: Let’s open some windows and air out this place.

meanings.definition: a plane or helicopter with all the equipment needed to fly sick or injured people to hospital
a device in a vehicle that very quickly fills with air in order to protect the driver or a passenger from injury when the vehicle is involved in an accident
a military airport where aircraft are kept and can land and take off
a place for the storage, operation, and care of military aircraft
a small bag of air or gas inside a fish's body, that helps it to float or breathe
a brake operated by air pressure, used on large vehicles such as buses and trains
an air route connecting two places that makes it possible for people or supplies, such as military equipment, to be transported into or out of an area:
examples: Tankers left to set up the air bridge that would move combat and cargo planes to the Middle East.
Mexico mounted an ambitious air bridge of helicopter shipments of tons of medicine to Nicaragua.

meanings.definition: an arrangement in which two countries agree that people can fly directly between them, without some of the rules and controls that affect travellers from other countries:
examples: Air bridges could allow people to travel freely between the UK and other specified countries without quarantine.

meanings.definition: a raised closed passage through which passengers walk from an airport building to an aircraft:
examples: Cracks in the tarmac mean that planes are unable to use 11 out of 51 air bridges for boarding aircraft.

meanings.definition: a person or organization that arranges the renting of planes, or that sells space on planes to people who need to transport goods by air:
examples: As a leading air broker, we can arrange the appropriate charter plane or executive jet for your needs.

meanings.definition: a ball of air that is surrounded by a liquid or by soft or frozen material:
examples: Make sure the paint is smooth, with no air bubbles.
The surface of the lake was disturbed only by occasional air bubbles from the divers.

meanings.definition: goods that are carried by plane:
examples: an air cargo carrier/company/service
the air cargo industry/market

meanings.definition: a piece of equipment that presses air into a smaller space so that it can be used under high pressure, for example for filling a tyre:
examples: You should also take a tool kit, air compressor (to pump up a flat tyre), first aid kit, and blanket.
The drill pulverises the rock using high power air compressors.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         air conditioning

abbreviation for
        
         air conditioning
a machine that keeps the air in a building cool
a machine that cools a room, building, or vehicle
the system used for keeping the air in a building or vehicle cool:
examples: I wish my car had air conditioning.

meanings.definition: a system for cooling a room, building, or vehicle
the electrical system used for keeping the air in a building, room, or vehicle cool:
examples: an air-conditioning system
All hotel rooms have air conditioning.

meanings.definition:
another word for 
        
         air traffic control
a person who manages aircraft from the ground as they take off, fly, and land:
examples: The pilot was advised by an air controller to turn back due to poor visibility.
The transponder allows air controllers to track a plane.

meanings.definition: a military officer who controls the movements and operation of military aircraft in an area:
examples: They were being guided to their targets by a forward air controller from the US Marine Corps.
The mission is planned in close coordination with ground commanders and tactical air controllers.
